title: this is football magic of the game
story: It can be hard in England to get a feel for the scale, the power and â€“ yes really â€“ the beauty of the Premier Leagueâ€™s vast global reach. Probably this has something to do with the way it is reflected back, most often through the wild frontier, the cranksâ€™ rodeo, the Hobby Horse Derby of social media.More toxic still is the way the Premier Leagueâ€™s commercial success is so often described as simply this and nothing more, couched in tones of crowing economic triumphalism that reduces its devotees to numbers, eyeballs, units of desire.The power of football, the magic of football. Terms such as these have become corrupted by corporate inanity. We think of advert-people: clear-eyed, face-painted, transported by tyre-excitement or Visa-magic, a place where love means consumption, where unity is a roster of approved exclusive rights holders. Welcome to a world where all the people like all the football â€“ and all the football is good. Little wonder it is hard to get a grip on this, to feel its human edges. But those edges are still there. Occasionally they appear in chastening, startling detail. This week I watched Redemption, the first episode of This Is Football, an Amazon Prime series that explores the magical power, the alchemy â€“ and so on â€“ of football and its supporters.So far, so familiar. The opening credits have Pep Guardiola sitting around looking damp-eyed and messianic and saying things like: â€œYou must ... love the ball.â€ A sonorous voice says: â€œFootball isnâ€™t a game. Itâ€™s emotion!â€, the kind of statement that makes you want to take the person who said it by the ear and tweak their nose and say really, really, is that actually true buckaroo?And then suddenly everything changes and Redemption takes us somewhere else entirely. The film follows the passionate familial love for Liverpool FC among a group of Rwandans, and the wider role football played in Rwandaâ€™s recovery from the wounds of its terrifyingly recent genocide. It is an extraordinary, redemptive piece of film-making by James Erskine, who also directed One Night In Turin, and with whom I worked briefly on the film From The Ashes. Thereâ€™s a beautiful opening shot, the camera panning over the dusty roads and jerry-built houses of Kigali, the Rwandan capital, set to the irresistibly cheese-laden, oddly intimate tones of Youâ€™ll Never Walk Alone.A group of men in red shirts are singing â€œWe are Liverpoolâ€ gently as they walk through the suburbs. This is the Rwanda Reds, a club for men and women who love Liverpool with a fervour that is initially quite startling. As darkness falls they start to hug and dance in front of the big screen, some crying and laughing at the same time. One man mentions he named his son after a noted local hero. His son is called â€œIan Rushâ€.There are two main characters. Thereâ€™s Joe, a ranger in the national park. We see him punching the air in the middle of the plains as Mo Salah scores a goal over the crackly radio in his Toyota pick-up. Joe sighs and says: â€œWhen Liverpool score â€¦ I feel my daddy. He is always watching, supporting Liverpool.â€ Then thereâ€™s Claude-Romeo, a little younger and about to get married, who says: â€œSome of us have lost our brothers and sisters. So the Liverpool shirt to me is a family.â€ These might sound like cliches anywhere else, the kind of thing Nero-era Sepp Blatter used to gabble about. But this isnâ€™t anywhere else.A bit later we discover that Joeâ€™s daddy, who he thinks about when Liverpool score and who loved Kenny Dalglish, was brutally murdered near the family home. Claude-Romeo doesnâ€™t have any bothers and sisters because, like so many other Rwandans, they were murdered during those hundred days in 1994 when a million Tutsis were slaughtered by their neighbours and countrymen.The Belgians brought football to Rwanda in the 19th century. They also brought ethnic ision, a fault-line of engineered social tension that would eventually come to a horrendous end. Football has been at the heart of Rwandaâ€™s efforts to recover from this trauma. Again, this is not a platitude. In the aftermath the game sprung up on every patch of land. Orphans, displaced people and half empty villages began to play together. Football became therapy, but also social glue. During the genocide Rwandan women suffered terrible abuse. A national programme of womenâ€™s football was introduced as a way of trying to encourage young women to â€œbe active, not taken over by the pastâ€.Eventually thousands of suspected mass murderers were released from the overcrowded prisons. They began to play football matches against the survivors. A kind of fraternity emerged. Forgiveness became possible. The famous African Cup Of Nations victory against Ghana in 2003 led to scenes of wild shared joy: â€œWe believed then that anything was possible.â€Twitter: follow us at @_sportFacebook: like our football and sport pagesInstagram: our favourite photos, films and storiesYouTube: subscribe to our football and sport channelsThe filmâ€™s absolute kick in the guts comes right at the end when suddenly Joe and Claude-Romeo are in Liverpool going to Anfield, talking about whether Roberto Firmino is going to start. Outside the ground they keep on grinning and hugging and laughing. Thereâ€™s Joe gazing up at the Kenny Dalglish stand. You know who heâ€™s thinking about. Finally they see the pitch and Joe has to stop and hold his head and take a breath, and by this stage, no Iâ€™m not crying, you are, Iâ€™m just looking out of the window and being quiet for a bit.It really is worth a watch. And please donâ€™t tell me about Starbucksâ€™s sponsorship, or indeed about the concerns over Rwandaâ€™s current regime, which have their place too. Itâ€™s just that Redemption isnâ€™t about these things. Itâ€™s about the actual power, the actual magic of this global sport something that has been owned and styled by the corporate arm but which has within it an unmapped, unmonetised sense of hope.

title: lets move to ceredigion
story: There are few places in better spirits than this remote and ancient placeWhatâ€™s going for it? Hardcore, the Cardigans. They take no nonsense. Owain Gwynedd, Cadwaladr ap Gruffydd and Gruffydd ap Rhys kicked out the Normans, razing the castle and building their own, thank you very much, which stands there to this day. The relative remoteness of Ceredigion, and, of course, the doughty character of its inhabitants, has long made this stretch of coast a bastion of Welsh culture and language. The nearby coast has everything from rugged cliffs and sandy beaches to secret coves â€“ not to mention dolphin sightings. Today, the castle, where the first eisteddfod was held, back in the misty reaches of time, is freshly renovated and revived, as a home to Welsh poetry jams and whatnot. And the rest of the town? Iâ€™ve rarely seen a place in better spirits. The high street is all bushy-tailed with Specsavers, nail bars, butchers, greengrocers beside sans-serif bakers and kool koffee spots with hashtags. Thereâ€™s culture aplenty: a great cinema, Theatr Mwldan, a film society, and an â€œalternativeâ€ theatre venue, the Small World Theatre. This is one of those corners of Wales that has long attracted outcasts and hippies, rat-race escapees, such as the brains behind the Meghan-sported Hiut jeans, and those who have frankly had enough of everything (who can blame them right now?).The case against Precious little. Unless you canâ€™t live without motorways and skyscrapers. Probably harder to find work unless you are Welsh-speaking.Well connected? On the edge of the country, obviously. Trains: no, the nearest stations are Carmarthen and Aberystwyth. Driving: 30 minutes to Aberaeron or Fishguard, 50 minutes to Carmarthen, one hour to Aberystwyth excellent coves and beaches such as Cilborth up the road. Decent local buses to destinations including Aberaeron (hourly, one hour) and Aberystwyth (hourly, one hour and 45 minutes).Schools Primaries: Gynradd Aberteifi has no inspection report, says Estyn, the education inspectorate for Wales. Secondaries: Uwchradd Aberteifi is â€œadequateâ€ with prospects for improvement â€œgoodâ€.Hang out atâ€¦ Lots to choose from: Fforestâ€™s Pizzatipi and Tafarn Smwglin. The Ferry Inn is lovely, or thereâ€™s 1176 for fancy. The addictive sourdough at Bara Menyn (Welsh for â€œbread and butterâ€) and newbie Crwst, a former hardware shop turned cafe.Where to buy Two choices. The Old Town, huddled round the castle and quayside, with lanes of brightly painted or grey-stone cottages and townhouses. Or the New Town, up the hill, for Victorians to moderns, townhouses to suburbans. Detacheds and townhouses, Â£200,000-Â£500,000. Semis, Â£100,000-Â£350,000. Terraced houses and cottages, Â£100,000-Â£175,000. Very little in the way of rentals.Bargain of the week Three-bedroom period terrace house in the Old Town, needs a bit of work, Â£95,000, with jjmorris.Kate Rhys â€œDonâ€™t even think of moving here unless you plan to learn and speak Welsh.â€ â€¢ Live in Cardigan? Join the debate belowDo you live in West Kirby? Do you have a favourite haunt or a pet hate? If so, email lets.move@the by Tuesday 30 July.

title: woodstock 50 festival maryland move
story: The 50th anniversary celebration of the hippie-era love-in is to move from upstate New York but that may not be enough to save itOrganizers of the beleaguered Woodstock 50 anniversary festival are planning to move the event to suburban Maryland in a last-ditch effort to salvage the half-centennial celebrations of the era-defining hippy love-in.The festival is now due to take place at the Merriweather Post Pavilion, a 32,000-capacity venue about 250 miles south of the original Woodstock site in Bethel, New York. It is scheduled to run from 16-18 August.The anniversary event has been spiralling out of control after the original ticket release was delayed, headliners including the Black Keys pulled out, and its financial backers, Dentsu Aegis, walked away, claiming the right to cancel the event entirely.Organizers, who include Woodstock 69â€™s original promoter, Michael Lang, initially decided that the original site was too small to hold enough people. They then lost the right to hold it at a larger venue in Watkins Glen, New York, after failing to make a payment. Less than a month ago, a third site at Vernon Downs in New York fell through when local officials said safety plans were â€œworthlessâ€.Calvin Ball, an executive at Marylandâ€™s Howard county, said Merriweather Post Pavilion â€œjumped at the chanceâ€ to save this festival and â€œbring a piece of American history to our community this summerâ€.â€œIt felt like such a natural fit to host a historic festival on our storied stage,â€ he wrote to organizers in a letter obtained by Bloomberg.But challenges remain. It is not clear whether the original lineup, which included Jay-Z, Miley Cyrus and Halsey, are obliged to perform if the event is held so far away. A source told the Associated Press that Jay-Z, who was due to close the festival, had indeed pulled out.According to Variety, touring agents are uniting against playing the new venue and demanding that artists be released from their contracts.â€œMost canâ€™t play Maryland and donâ€™t want to be involved in an event that is not properly conceived and developed,â€ says one industry insider. â€œWe took it as far down the road as we could. The clock just ran out.â€The eventâ€™s purpose has shifted: it is no longer being promoted as a commercial festival but as a fundraiser for groups promoting voter turnout and the climate crisis. Given the new venueâ€™s proximity to the capital, the name has changed to â€œWoodstock 50 Washingtonâ€.According to current plans, entry prices will go on sale at $129 to $595 for a one-day pass and itâ€™s being marketed to 800,000 people across Washington DC, Maryland and northern Virginia. The original event was characterized by chaos and astonishing performances by Sly and the Family Stone, Janis Joplin, the Who and Jimi Hendrix.Woodstock 50 Washington will not be the only commemorative event. The original site in Bethel, New York, is also holding a weekend of concerts featuring shows by Santana, Ringo Starr and John Fogerty.

title: dominic cummings was doorman at europes worst nightclub
story: Uncle of Boris Johnsonâ€™s strategist owned â€˜infamously badâ€™ Klute in DurhamWhile the role that Boris Johnsonâ€™s new adviser Dominic Cummings played in the Vote Leave campaign is well-established, his links to another disruptive force in British public life are less well known.Klute nightclub in Durham, with its sticky floors, strong drinks and unapologetically cheesy music, boasts of having been a favourite of the cityâ€™s students for more than 40 years.The 400-capacity club was apparently awarded the title of second worst nightclub in Europe by FHM magazine, before the venue in first place burned down, leaving Klute to take the top spot by default.The club was owned by Cummingsâ€™ uncle Phil and in his youth the political adviser reportedly helped him to run it. While the business was bought by Tokyo Industries in 2013, Cummings is still listed as the only director of a dormant company called Klute Limited.The announcement on Wednesday that Cummings â€“ the former head of the Vote Leave campaign â€“ would be a senior adviser to Boris Johnson was seen as hugely controversial. The former aide to Michael Gove as education secretary was found in contempt of parliament in March for failing to appear before MPs investigating the proliferation of false news stories during the EU referendum campaign.Cummings, the son of an oil rig project manager and a special needs teacher, was born in Durham in 1971. He attended the fee-paying Durham school, before going on to study at the University of Oxford.In January, the Sunday Express reported that Cummings had worked as a doorman at Klute at weekends. â€œHe might not have looked like a doorman,â€ a former colleague told the paper. â€œBut he had a way with him that suggested it wasnâ€™t worth taking him on.â€One fellow Eurosceptic campaigner told the  about a particularly drunken night there with Cummings in 2005. â€œWe went there after dinner and we were completely battered by the time we got to Klute. Itâ€™s a long time ago and I was very drunk, but Iâ€™m pretty sure we were taken into some sort of VIP area,â€ he said.â€œEveryone had been going on at me beforehand about how terrible it was. It was infamously bad, and even Dom was making jokes about it, but I got there and thought: â€˜This is quite niceâ€™.â€He remembers drinking a range of cocktails including â€œcheeky vimtosâ€ â€“ usually made from port and the alcopop WKD Blue. â€œPeople were dressed up for a good night out in the way people in London donâ€™t really,â€ he said. â€œIt was just a very normal, fun night out.â€In a comment thread on the Student Room website from 2009, one student described Klute as â€œa cheese-infested hellholeâ€. Another from 2005 described it as â€œsweaty, a bit gross, moody bouncersâ€, adding more cheerfully: â€œdouble and mixer Â£2â€.These days the club seems to have embraced its down-at-heel image, adopting the tagline: â€œWipe your feet on the way out.â€After visiting the club in 2014, the Vice journalist Jonny Chadwick concluded that it was â€œthe best example of the worst kind of club nightâ€.â€œThis sweatbox of unpleasant humans, terrible music and unbearable odours probably deserves its place at the top of the podium,â€ he said.

title: priti patel accused of breaching ministerial code for second time
story: Home secretary took up Â£1,000 an hour advisory role before getting watchdogâ€™s approvalThe new home secretary, Priti Patel, is facing allegations of breaching the ministerial code for the second time in her parliamentary career for accepting a lucrative position with a global communications firm before receiving the all-clear from an anti-corruption watchdog.Patel has been working for Viasat, a California-based company with a UK base in Farnborough, for the past three months as a strategic adviser on a salary of Â£5,000 a month for five hoursâ€™ work â€“ or Â£1,000 an hour.The ministerial code states former ministers must seek guidance from the advisory committee on business appointments (Acoba) on taking up any business appointments within two years of leaving the role â€“ and must not take up the position until advice has been received.Patel did not approach Acoba to seek advice on the Viasat appointment until June 2019 â€“ a month after she had started the role, in which she was advising on unspecified matters relating to India. She did not receive any guidance from the committee until earlier this month, by which time she had already earned Â£10,000.Patel has been approached for comment by the .The Essex MP was forced to resign from the cabinet in November 2017 as international development secretary when she was accused of breaching the ministerial code over unauthorised meetings with Israeli politicians. Patel conceded in her resignation letter that her actions fell below standards of transparency and openness required.Jon Trickett, the shadow minister for the Cabinet Office, has written to the new prime minister, Boris Johnson, calling for an investigation into whether Patel has broken the ministerial code, and has called for her dismissal if this is found to be the case. Johnson himself has breached the code in the past when he resumed writing for the  after resigning as foreign secretary he failed to declare the role with Acoba.Trickett said: â€œVery few people will be surprised that Boris Johnsonâ€™s cabinet is embroiled in scandal less than 48 hours after being appointed, yet it is still deeply worrying.â€œIt is an early sign that Johnsonâ€™s hard-right government will have little regard for the standards expected of ministers, by the ministerial code and by the public.â€œWhen she resigned in 2017, Patel spoke of her failure to uphold the necessary â€˜standards of transparency and opennessâ€™. It appears she has done so again.â€œClearly Patel does not think the rules apply to her, and the same could be said of many others in Johnsonâ€™s cabinet. Johnson must immediately sanction an investigation to confirm whether Patel has yet again broken the code, and reassure the public that his government will not tolerate those that disregard it so lightly.â€œI have written to the prime minister to ensure that this course of action is taken immediately.â€Acoba approved the appointment but with strict conditions. The committee said given her seniority and profile as a secretary of state there was a risk that it could be perceived Patelâ€™s contacts â€œmight assist Viasat unfairlyâ€.As a result, Acoba said Patel could take up the appointment but should not draw on any privileged information available from her time as international development secretary, should not lobby the UK government on behalf of Viasat and should not provide provide advice on any contracts with the UK government.Viasat provides products and services to the Ministry of Defence. It also works with the UK Space Agency, an executive agency sponsored by the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy.Section 7.25 of the code states that ministers â€œmust â€¦ seek advice from the independent advisory committee on business appointments (Acoba) about any appointments or employment they wish to take up within two years of leaving office.â€This section of the code also states that â€œformer ministers must ensure that no new appointments are announced, or taken up, before the committee has been able to provide its adviceâ€.

title: the comma touch jacob rees mogg sends language rules to staff
story: Commons leader reportedly wants his team to use imperial measurements and avoid saying â€˜veryâ€™A list of rules has been sent to Jacob Rees-Moggâ€™s staff asking them to stop using words such as â€œhopefullyâ€ and demanding that they use only imperial measurements and give all non-titled males the suffix Esq.Aides to the new leader of the House of Commons sent out the list shortly after Rees-Moggâ€™s appointment to the role by the new prime minister on Wednesday night.Among the words and phrases considered unacceptable were: â€œveryâ€, â€œdue toâ€ and â€œongoingâ€, as well as â€œequalâ€, â€œyourselfâ€ and â€œunacceptableâ€. Rees-Moggâ€™s aides also barred the use of â€œlotâ€, â€œgotâ€ and â€œI am pleased to learnâ€.The guidance, obtained by ITV news, was drawn up by the North East Somerset MPâ€™s constituency team years ago, but has now been shared with officials in his new office.In a call for accuracy contained in his list, staff were told: â€œCHECK your work.â€ Other directions include a call for a double space after full stops and no comma after the word â€œandâ€.Staff should avoid â€œtoo many â€˜Isâ€™â€ in their writing, Rees-Moggâ€™s team has ordered, and he would neither â€œnoteunderstand your concernsâ€, nor would he welcome calls to â€œinvest (in schools, etc)â€. Moreover, the phrase â€œno longer fit for purposeâ€ has been deemed no longer fit for purpose.The official transcript of parliamentary proceedings, Hansard, records more than 700 instances of Rees-Mogg using one or other of the banned words or phrases.As chair of the European Research Group â€“ an influential, hard-Brexit Tory backbench grouping â€“ Rees-Mogg has increased his influence in Westminster in recent years.He is an Old Etonian, like the prime minister he serves, and, like the prime minister he serves, has cultivated a reputation for formality and upper-class eccentricity, gaining the nickname the â€œhonourable member for the 18th centuryâ€. When standing for the Conservatives for the Central Fife seat in 1997, he took his nanny and his motherâ€™s Mercedes out canvassing.Rees-Mogg has also used his position of influence to argue against abortion, even in cases of rape, and same-sex marriage.He has been one of the most prominent backers of a hard Brexit and, last year, it was revealed that a City firm he co-founded had set up an investment fund in Ireland and was warning prospective clients about the financial dangers of a hard Brexit.Following his appointment by Johnson this week, he is responsible for organising government business in the Commons.The Commons leaderâ€™s office would not comment on the leaked document.

title: share your experiences of netball
story: Following New Zealand winning the Womenâ€™s Netball World Cup, we would like to hear your stories of playing the sportThe world of women and sport is rapidly changing. The unprecedented coverage of both the Womenâ€™s football World Cup and the Netball World Cup have dictated this on an international platform. The rippling effect of the #thisgirlcan movement can still be felt almost five years on since it launched, the aim of which was to increase participation levels of girls and women in sport. In many scenarios, it is more than just a competitive game. It is a social space, where women can come together and set aside time for themselves. At club level, the sport s across generations, with many women in their 30s and 40s returning to the sport of their youth. The ever-growing popularity of the sport prompted Sport England to award it a 16.9m government grant in 2017, 10.5m of which was set to encourage women to take up the sport again.Netball has always been at the forefront of this push. Often the first sport many young girls are introduced to, teaching important lessons such as teamwork, competition and integration, we want to hear your netball memories and experiences.Did you watch the Netball World Cup? What effect did it have on you and what do you remember from when you used to play? If you are someone who has returned to the sport, what has your experience been like? Does your team  across all generations?You can share your photos and stories in the encrypted form below. We will feature a selection of responses in our reporting.If youâ€™re having trouble using the form, click here. Read terms of service here.

title: england australia womens ashes t20 cricket match report
story: In a show of utter dominance Australia ground Englandâ€™s hopes of drawing this Ashes series firmly into the dust, the visitors smashing their record T20 total while Meg Lanning racked up an unbeaten 133 from 63 balls to break her own record for the highest inidual score in the format.England, by contrast, could manage just the same number of runs as Lanning as they fell to a 93-run defeat, their worst in T20.â€œIt was a pretty sweet victory,â€ Lanning said. â€œWe came here to win the Ashes outright and thatâ€™s what weâ€™ve done.â€â€œI hit the ball as well I have for a long time,â€ she added. â€œI was getting some starts but getting out all the time â€“ that was annoying me. So when I did get a start I was keen to start putting the foot down and take the opportunity because that doesnâ€™t come along very often. It was nice to be able to cash in.â€The match was all-but decided in the first three overs of Englandâ€™s reply: the home side sinking to 12 for three as the openers, Danni Wyatt and Amy Jones, departed without scoring, looking to slog, while Tammy Beaumont then toed a catch to Alyssa Healy behind the stumps.A brave effort from the No 6, Lauren Winfield, selected for the first time this series, was followed by a 12-ball 25-run cameo from Laura Marsh both came too late to make much difference to a day that had been all about Lanning.This was supposed to have been Englandâ€™s prime opportunity to turn the series on its head: on 14 previous occasions, they had never lost a match here where the crowds are so partisan and raucous that it has earned the moniker â€œFortress Chelmsfordâ€. This time the sell-out crowd sounded anything but, sinking into themselves as they searched in vain for something to cheer.Kate Crossâ€™s first over, with Healy skying the fifth ball of the innings to Nat Sciver at midwicket, was as good as it got for the home crowd. From there, with Lanning entering the fray, it was all systems go: Anya Shrubsole hit out of the attack as her first over went for 16 runs, while the early switch to spin failed to stem the flow â€“ Sophie Ecclestone punished for nearly 11 an over.Along the way Lanning was ably supported by Beth Mooney, who hit a 28-ball half-century, and Ash Gardner, who smashed the biggest six of the innings off a disgruntled Shrubsole.Some have questioned whether undergoing major shoulder surgery 18 months ago has stymied Lanningâ€™s international dominance. This performance showed that she is back with a vengeance, the Australian captain smashing seven sixes with such ease that one feels her shoulder surgeon should use the videotape of this innings to advertise his services to future clients.Lanningâ€™s half-century took 24 balls to acquire: 27 balls later came the three-figure milestone, brought up in style with yet another six smashed over deep square-leg.As any statistician will tell you, numbers have to be contextualised. Lanningâ€™s previous T20 century had been against Ireland, ranked 10th: perhaps the most astonishing thing about Fridayâ€™s display was that it was against a side who, after reaching the final of the World T20 eight months ago, can lay claim to being the second-best T20 team in the world. They did not look it: even Wyatt, Englandâ€™s best fielder, was gifting boundaries in the deep, while Beaumont made the fatal error of dropping Lanning at point, a mistake that cost 48 runs.â€œWe havenâ€™t played anywhere near our potential,â€ Heather Knight, the England captain, said. â€œThe girls are disappointed, itâ€™s been a tricky few weeks for us â€“ weâ€™ve lost a bit of belief and confidence.â€â€œWeâ€™ve got to get back to the way we know we can play. When weâ€™re at our best weâ€™re competitive, weâ€™re happy, weâ€™re smiley, weâ€™re buzzing, all that sort of thing, so itâ€™s about getting back to our roots as a team that have served us well.â€Before Friday night, it would have been possible to argue that this Ashes series â€“ bar one crazy afternoon at Canterbury â€“ has been evenly matched: not any more.

title: joe root substandard lords pitch england ireland test
story: Englandâ€™s bowlers will not thank Joe Root for it but their captain was highly critical of the Lordâ€™s pitch after his sideâ€™s 143-run victory against Ireland. â€œI donâ€™t like saying this but the wicket was substandard for a Test match,â€ Root said after Ireland were bowled out for 38. â€œIt wasnâ€™t even close to being a fair contest between bat and ball throughout the whole game.â€He admitted his team â€œwerenâ€™t at our best by any stretchâ€ but, in what came across as a pretty clear dig at the Lordâ€™s groundsman, Karl McDermott, Root said: â€œWhen you are getting scores like that, that tells a story in itself.â€McDermott, who took over the job only last December, has just over a fortnight to get his surface ready for the second Ashes Test. Root said he hoped the pitch would be better than this one. â€œWeâ€™ll have to wait and see if it is similar,â€ he said. â€œI donâ€™t think it will be.â€If it is, England â€œwill have to make sure we try to exploit it the best we can, to find a method to cope and score runs. The challenge will be the same for Australia as it was for us and Ireland this week. It will make for entertaining cricket if thatâ€™s the case.â€The blunt truth is that it was not only the pitch that was substandard but the batting too, since both teams were bowled out in the space of a single session. Root insisted â€œfrom a batting point of view, itâ€™s hard to take too much out of it on a surface like thatâ€ and that â€œitâ€™s hard for anyone to read too much into this in very extreme conditionsâ€.He did admit â€œwe have got to be more precise about how we want to defendâ€ and that he was personally responsible for â€œopening the door for Irelandâ€ in the second innings, when he â€œstupidlyâ€ ran out Joe Denly.Lurking in the background behind all this talk about the pitch, there is a suggestion that Root and the other players who turned out for England in the World Cup are exhausted. Root did not deny he was feeling â€œknackeredâ€ and said: â€œItâ€™s been 10 weeks of hard cricket, of high emotion, of ups and downs. It does take a lot out of you.â€He did not want to make an excuse of it. â€œYou have to suck it up and get on with it. Itâ€™s not been perfect but weâ€™ve dealt with it pretty well. Itâ€™s hard to look too much into performances on there but mentally coping with it I think weâ€™ve done all right.â€œWeâ€™ve never been in a position where weâ€™ve won a World Cup, so for half the side to be part of that and then very quickly adjust to Test cricket is unusual. Youâ€™ve never been in that position before, so itâ€™s hard to know how youâ€™re going to cope.â€Personally he had turned up at Lordâ€™s â€œfeeling extremely excited for the Test summerâ€ and now its preface was over he felt â€œpleased we managed to find a way to win this game. Thereâ€™s been so many different pressures and challenges thrown at usâ€.There have but it is all about to get that much more pressured and that much more challenging again. The hard part is only just starting.

title: sebastian vettel ferrari future german grand prix
story: Sebastian Vettel, despite everything, is still smiling. The equanimity with which he faces his shortcomings this season and the realisation his Ferrari team cannot challenge Mercedes for the Formula One title, says much for his character.Yet competing in the 11 remaining races in a car with which he is struggling weighs heavy and that smile must be beginning to fade. Little wonder that debate in the paddock before his home race at the German Grand Prix on Sunday revolves around whether he will retire at the end of the season.At 32, Vettel has four titles, all for Red Bull between 2010 and 2013. He joined Ferrari in 2015 with the intent of emulating Michael Schumacher, building the team around him and returning their first driversâ€™ championship since 2007. What followed has been a rollercoaster of optimism and shattered hopes that could easily break a driver. Vettel insists he will see out his final season with Ferrari next year before deciding on his future.This season is already gone, with Vettel 100 points behind Lewis Hamilton, and Mercedes holding a distinct advantage. Once again the hope of a Ferrari challenge has disappeared, dispiritingly almost from the opening race. The Scuderia, who had backed Vettel as their No 1 driver from the off, appear to have given the German a car that simply does not suit him.In the 2015 and 2016 seasons, Ferrari were blown away by the dominant Mercedes. By 2017 they were in a position to mount a challenge and last year were even stronger, with the superior car for much of the season. Errors by driver and team proved costly and their hopes slipped away.Last year Vettel went off at Hockenheim while leading in the rain, the low point of a season peppered with mistakes. This year he spun while in competition with Hamilton in Bahrain, and in Canada went off when under pressure from the British driver. At the last race at Silverstone, his misjudgment in crashing into Max Verstappen was as public and as egregious an error as he has made since Spa 2010 when he lost control at the Bus Stop and hit Jenson Button.He has admitted he is more than aware of his failings. â€œI always put myself under pressure, so I canâ€™t be happy if things go wrong,â€ he said. â€œThe pressure I put on myself after that is bigger than any external factors. For me itâ€™s the most honest and straightforward way to deal with it myself, because I know what Iâ€™ve done wrong and what Iâ€™ve done right.â€The incident at the British Grand Prix was seen as an error indicative of a driver struggling for confidence. Alain Prost singled it out. â€œThe collision at Silverstone happened due to a lack of judgment. We clearly see that he is not in top form,â€ he said. â€œIt is due to a lack of sufficient concentration, motivation or judgment.â€At Hockenheim Vettel has insisted it is a privilege not a burden to race for Ferrari. However Johnny Herbert, who raced alongside Michael Schumacher at Benetton in 1995, is convinced that representing the Scuderia lies heavy on Vettel. â€œSebastian still has to carry Ferrari on this shoulders,â€ he said. â€œThe pressure of Italy, of the team, of the media. In the last couple of years they havenâ€™t taken that pressure off. That massive weight hasnâ€™t allowed him to breathe. Ferrari havenâ€™t got that balance right, a driver needs that.â€But what seems equally as important as where Vettel is mentally is what he is feeling through the seat of his pants. His titles were won during the blown diffuser period of 2010-2011 and then when it was banned, Red Bull maintained their advantage by clever channelling of exhaust gasses in 2012-2013. The period was one where downforce was dominant and Vettel was its master.He likes to arrive fast into the corner, brake late and turn-in aggressively, before getting back on the power. The Red Bull suited this to perfection, he had the front end he needed for corner entry and the confidence that the grip would be there when he hit the throttle on exit.When the Red Bull struggled with rear stability early in one season, Vettelâ€™s teammate Mark Webber had an edge. As the team solved the problem, the car came to Vettel, as did the title. In 2014 when all exhaust blowing was removed Vettel looked uncomfortable, did not win a race and was beaten by his inexperienced teammate Daniel Ricciardo.This season Ferrari will have endeavoured to build a car to suit Vettel, instead they have delivered what appears to be the opposite, a car with inherent understeer. Worse still he has struggled to adapt to it. Since the Canadian GP he has been outqualified and outperformed by his Ferrari teammate Charles Leclerc in every race. Leclerc seems more adept at being able to hustle the car through the corners.â€œIf I donâ€™t feel what I need itâ€™s a bit tricky,â€ Vettel said of his car in 2018 at Melbourne. It is a view with which Herbert concurs. â€œThe car is not what he wants,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s not delivering what he needs to feel through the tips of his fingers and his shoulders and when you donâ€™t have that feeling you are going to struggle and then the mental side comes in.â€The Ferrari team principal, Mattia Binotto, has held up his hands in admitting the car is not where it should be but publicly Vettel remains committed to his task. This year he married his childhood sweetheart with whom he has two children and while he enjoys a life away from F1 at Hockenheim he reiterated his intent to see out his time with Ferrari. Having put four years in already and still smiling, Vettel knows there is still a job to be done with the team.â€œHe went to Ferrari to try to win a championship, he has not achieved that,â€ Herbert said. â€œI would be so surprised if he walked away having not achieved that. I would be shocked if he did that. The opportunity is still there. He has not finished the job he went there to do.â€At their home race Mercedes are running a white livery to celebrate 125 years since what is considered the first race held in 1894 from Paris to Rouen. Ferrari however had the edge in Fridayâ€™s first practice session. Vettel was quickest with Leclerc second in front of Hamilton and the Red Bull of Max Verstappen. The Ferrari teammates traded places in the afternoon session with Leclerc holding a 0.124sec advantage. Hamilton again had to settle for third, 0.146sec off Leclercâ€™s pace. Mercedes, struggling in the fierce temperatures as they had in Austria, will be hoping for cooler weather.

title: barber shop chronicles review roundhouse inua ellams
story: Roundhouse theatre, LondonInua Ellamsâ€™ play hurtles between London and Africa, so full is it of authentic male dialogue and connectionsEven the clock moves at double time. A show set in a series of barberâ€™s shops sounds like a potentially sedentary affair but Bijan Sheibaniâ€™s vibrant production â€“ which transfers to the Roundhouse after two sell-out runs at the National and a whirlwind world tour â€“ never stops moving. We roam across shops, shacks and stalls in London and throughout Africa and barely pause for breath. Rae Smithâ€™s makeshift set is on wheels, the barberâ€™s chairs are on wheels, possibly even the actors are on wheels. Inua Ellamsâ€™ beautifully observed work is a pulsing and poetic delight a sweeping snapshot of life as an African man as a dizzying host of customers take a seat, relax and let us into their lives.Ellams spent six weeks in Africa researching his play, whittling 60 hours of recordings down into this two-hour show. Sometimes the script is almost too rich â€“ thereâ€™s so much information to take in â€“ but itâ€™s an undeniably beautiful thing, packed with authentic dialogue and stunning flashes of insight.Thereâ€™s passionate political and personal debate as the men discuss Mugabe, Mandela, fallen leaders and absent fathers. Perhaps the most surprising aspect is just how tender this all-male play feels. Sure, thereâ€™s posturing and showboating, especially when Demmy Ladipoâ€™s â€œbad boyâ€ is showing off to the lads. But there are so many gentle moments in here too: a hard-up old man is given a free haircut a barber offers a young dad some beautiful advice (â€œListen to your child â€“ he will teach you the right languageâ€) and an anxious young actor finds a place to relax and confess his fears.Itâ€™s not just about the dialogue, either. There are the music and movement, overseen by Elander Moore, which infuse the scene-changes with energy and purpose. There are also the collective sighs, groans and cheers, as the men talk, listen and, of course, watch football. Best of all are the grunts of delight, as each man is shown his new haircut in the mirror. The customers smile and whoop at their reflections, happy â€“ in this safe environment â€“ with the men they see.â€¢ At the Roundhouse, London, until 24 August.

title: apple contractors regularly hear confidential details on siri recordings
story: Workers hear drug deals, medical details and people having sex, says whistleblowerApple contractors regularly hear confidential medical information, drug deals, and recordings of couples having sex, as part of their job providing quality control, or â€œgradingâ€, the companyâ€™s Siri voice assistant, the  has learned.Although Apple does not explicitly disclose it in its consumer-facing privacy documentation, a small proportion of Siri recordings are passed on to contractors working for the company around the world. They are tasked with grading the responses on a variety of factors, including whether the activation of the voice assistant was deliberate or accidental, whether the query was something Siri could be expected to help with and whether Siriâ€™s response was appropriate.Apple says the data â€œis used to help Siri and dictation â€¦ understand you better and recognise what you sayâ€.But the company does not explicitly state that that work is undertaken by humans who listen to the pseudonymised recordings.A whistleblower working for the firm, who asked to remain anonymous due to fears over their job, expressed concerns about this lack of disclosure, particularly given the frequency with which accidental activations pick up extremely sensitive personal information.Siri can be accidentally activated when it mistakenly hears its â€œwake wordâ€, the phrase â€œhey Siriâ€. Those mistakes can be understandable â€“ a BBC interview about Syria was interrupted by the assistant last year â€“ or less so. â€œThe sound of a zip, Siri often hears as a trigger,â€ the contractor said. The service can also be activated in other ways. For instance, if an Apple Watch detects it has been raised and then hears speech, Siri is automatically activated.The whistleblower said: â€œThere have been countless instances of recordings featuring private discussions between doctors and patients, business deals, seemingly criminal dealings, sexual encounters and so on. These recordings are accompanied by user data showing location, contact details, and app data.â€That accompanying information may be used to verify whether a request was successfully dealt with. In its privacy documents, Apple says the Siri data â€œis not linked to other data that Apple may have from your use of other Apple servicesâ€. There is no specific name or identifier attached to a record and no inidual recording can be easily linked to other recordings.Accidental activations led to the receipt of the most sensitive data that was sent to Apple. Although Siri is included on most Apple devices, the contractor highlighted the Apple Watch and the companyâ€™s HomePod smart speaker as the most frequent sources of mistaken recordings. â€œThe regularity of accidental triggers on the watch is incredibly high,â€ they said. â€œThe watch can record some snippets that will be 30 seconds â€“ not that long but you can gather a good idea of whatâ€™s going on.â€Sometimes, â€œyou can definitely hear a doctor and patient, talking about the medical history of the patient. Or youâ€™d hear someone, maybe with car engine background noise â€“ you canâ€™t say definitely, but itâ€™s a drug deal â€¦ you can definitely hear it happening. And youâ€™d hear, like, people engaging in sexual acts that are accidentally recorded on the pod or the watch.â€The contractor said staff were encouraged to report accidental activations â€œbut only as a technical problemâ€, with no specific procedures to deal with sensitive recordings. â€œWeâ€™re encouraged to hit targets, and get through work as fast as possible. The only function for reporting what youâ€™re listening to seems to be for technical problems. Thereâ€™s nothing about reporting the content.â€As well as the discomfort they felt listening to such private information, the contractor said they were motivated to go public about their job because of their fears that such information could be misused. â€œThereâ€™s not much vetting of who works there, and the amount of data that weâ€™re free to look through seems quite broad. It wouldnâ€™t be difficult to identify the person that youâ€™re listening to, especially with accidental triggers â€“ addresses, names and so on.The contractor argued Apple should reveal to users this human oversight exists â€“ and, specifically, stop publishing some of its jokier responses to Siri queries. Ask the personal assistant â€œare you always listeningâ€, for instance, and it will respond with: â€œI only listen when youâ€™re talking to me.â€That is patently false,, the contractor said. They argued that accidental triggers are too regular for such a lighthearted response.Apple is not alone in employing human oversight of its automatic voice assistants. In April, Amazon was revealed to employ staff to listen to some Alexa recordings, and earlier this month, Google workers were found to be doing the same with Google Assistant.The company values its reputation for user privacy highly, regularly wielding it as a competitive advantage against Google and Amazon. In January, it bought a billboard at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas announcing that â€œwhat happens on your iPhone stays on your iPhoneâ€.

title: whisky business how do you drink yours
story: For too long a snobbery has lingered over how best to consume whisky. Can there really be a right â€“ or wrong â€“ way to enjoy your favourite malt?It can often seem as if there are only two schools of thought when it comes to how you should enjoy your whisky. Some treat the drink with an almost austere reverence, insisting that it should only be taken neat or with just a touch of water â€“ maybe, at a pinch, with an ice cube or two. Others, which in reality means most people who enjoy a tipple every now and then, are happy to mix it to taste with whatever works for them, use it as a base for a cocktail, or simply sip it from a mighty tumbler towering with ice.But is there a right way to drink whisky? It might be that you can do whatever you want with the house blend down at your local pub, but what about something more refined â€“ in other words, what about a single malt?For the uninitiated, the distinction between a blend and a single malt is a fairly easy one to mark out. A scotch blend is simply a mixture of grain and malt whiskies from two or more distilleries. A single malt, on the other hand, is nothing more and nothing less than a whisky from a single distillery, bottled and sold as a whisky from a single distillery.But, of course, things are always a little more complicated than that. Blends are sometimes thought to be inferior to their single malt cousins, and while this is by no means a settled question, it is true that they donâ€™t quite inspire the same scholarly devotion as single malts. So, while plenty of whisky purists may have no problem with you topping up an inexpensive blend with a yard of Coke, theyâ€™re likely to take a less charitable view of you doing the same with their favourite malt.Luckily, there is an answer to all of this.â€œIt really just depends on what youâ€™re looking for,â€ says Kirstie McCallum, senior blender at Distell International, which owns and produces Tobermory. â€œFor me thereâ€™s a real difference between wanting to sit there and appreciate a whisky for all its flavours and complexity, and just actually wanting to sit there and enjoy a drink with friends.â€œIf I want to appreciate all the flavours in a whisky and appreciate that maturation and the work thatâ€™s gone into it I love it with just a wee touch of water to open it up,â€ she says. â€œThen just sip it, let it rest in your mouth a bit so that you get a proper chance to take in all of the flavours. At the same time, if youâ€™re just sitting around having a drink with your friends, do whatever you want with it.â€McCallumâ€™s refreshingly unpretentious take is rooted in her view that whisky â€“ and that includes single malts â€“ is on the whole a social, relaxed drink. That means there is plenty of room at the table both for those who want to contemplate their whisky â€“ either neat or, as she prefers it, with a touch of water â€“ and those who want to let their hair down a bit more.â€œI think for too long whisky has been seen as kind of standoffish,â€ she says. â€œThereâ€™s always been this view of whisky that itâ€™s maybe a bit like how people see wine â€“ they worry about not knowing what to ask for or about getting it wrong somehow. But whisky shouldnâ€™t be like that at all, because itâ€™s a drink for everybody.â€œWe make the whisky for people to drink it, and whatever you like adding to it, as long as you enjoy it thatâ€™s how you should drink it,â€ says McCallum. â€œThe great thing is that whisky is just such a versatile drink. You can do cocktails with whisky, you can do long drinks, or you can have a nice single malt with water.â€With that in mind, McCallum suggests a number of tantalising options for enjoying Tobermory 12 Year Old. â€œI think with Tobermory being such a citrusy, caramelly, kind of sweet whisky, it mixes well with something thatâ€™s nice and light and fresh,â€ she says.â€œIt works really well as a long mixed drink with lots of ice. Iâ€™d recommend trying it that way with either ginger ale or some fresh apple juice,â€ she says.On the cocktail front, McCallum says that the citrus and caramel notes of Tobermory 12 Year Old are particularly complemented by berry flavours â€“ so a Scotch bramble, or perhaps a malt old fashioned with a blueberry garnish, could be well worth trying.â€œFor me, whisky is a very personal drink,â€ she says. â€œI drink my whisky and itâ€™s about memories of being places and being with friends â€“ itâ€™s not about â€˜you canâ€™t do this and you canâ€™t do thatâ€™. In the end, itâ€™s about enjoying it on your own terms â€“ do whatever you want with it.â€To learn more about the art of the Hebridean distillers visit tobermorydistillery

title: house democrats mueller grand jury evidence impeachment
story: Lawmakers say they need evidence to determine impeachment proceedings as they file lawsuit to compel testimony from McGahnThe Democratic-led US House judiciary committee is filing an application to seek access to grand jury evidence from the Mueller investigation, which lawmakers say they need to determine whether to begin impeachment proceedings against Donald Trump.A second pending legal move by Democrats, a federal lawsuit to compel testimony from former White House counsel Don McGahn about the Republican presidentâ€™s efforts to impede the Mueller investigation, is expected early next week.The grand jury evidence, which is protected from outside scrutiny by federal law, was compiled by former special counsel Robert Muellerâ€™s 22-month investigation of Russian meddling in the 2016 presidential election and the Trump campaignâ€™s links with Moscow.The House judiciary committee chairman, Jerry Nadler, told a news conference that since justice department policy prohibits the prosecution of a sitting president, the House of Representatives was the only institution of government capable of holding Trump accountable for actions outlined in the Mueller report.â€œThe House must have access to all the relevant facts and consider whether to exercise its full â€¦ powers, including a constitutional power of the utmost gravity: recommendation of articles of impeachment,â€ Nadler said, reading from the court petition.He also said Muellerâ€™s grand jury information â€œis critically important for our ability to examine witnesses, including former White House counsel Don McGahn, and to investigate the presidentâ€™s misconductâ€.The committeeâ€™s Democrats, who flanked Nadler at the news conference, said the pending court petition was a new step toward impeachment and described their ongoing obstruction of justice investigation against Trump as an â€œimpeachment investigationâ€, though the panel has not officially launched an impeachment inquiry.Many reports have indicated that Nadler has privately voiced support for launching an impeachment inquiry, but he has declined to do so publicly.When asked by a CNN reporter why he has chosen not to do so, Nadler notably paused before dodging the question. One of the panelâ€™s other members, the Pennsylvania representative Mary Gay Scanlon, then took the microphone to argue that impeachment â€œisnâ€™t a binary thingâ€.The top Republican on the judiciary committee, the Georgia representative Doug Collins, criticized Nadlerâ€™s move.â€œJudiciary Democrats are suing for grand jury material to which they have no right,â€ Collins said in a statement. â€œChairman Nadlerâ€™s legal action here is sure to fail, weakening Congressâ€™s ability to conduct oversight now and into the future.â€œNadler described the pending legal actions, including the McGahn lawsuit, as a potential watershed that could dismantle recent White House efforts to stonewall congressional investigators by directing current and former Trump aides to defy subpoenas and refrain from providing testimony.Mueller testified on Wednesday in back-to-back hearings that Democrats hoped would focus public attention on Trumpâ€™s alleged misconduct and boost support for an impeachment inquiry. But his halting and reticent performance changed few opinions, leaving House Democrats to accelerate a congressional inquiry that could take months to bear fruit.The House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, who opposes impeachment for now as a politically risky move for Democrats, told reporters that she favored litigation to obtain â€œthe best, strongest possible caseâ€ against Trump.But with the 2020 election campaign season fast approaching, she also made it clear that the impeachment issue would not be allowed to linger.â€œThe decision will be made in a timely fashion. This isnâ€™t endless,â€ said Pelosi, who denied suggestions that she was trying to â€œrun out the clockâ€ on impeachment.Mueller found insufficient evidence to allege that the Trump campaign conspired with Moscow in its effort to help Trump get elected in 2016, although campaign officials met with Russians.He also reached no conclusions on whether Trump tried to obstruct Muellerâ€™s inquiry.But he has also said the report does not exonerate the president. The 448-page document outlines 10 incidents of potential obstruction.Democrats say that testimony from McGahn could give them the evidence they need for an impeachment inquiry. McGahn told special counsel investigators that Trump directed him to seek Muellerâ€™s removal and then to deny that he had been instructed to do so.Democrats view the alleged episode as an act of obstruction of justice.McGahn declined to testify earlier this year after the White House directed him not to cooperate with the committee.Reuters contributed to this report

title: mueller testimony democrats impeachment
story: The special counsel sent a clear signal impeachment is not the way to go, experts say, despite the many Democrats in favourCameras stood ready. Photographers crouched. Reporters sat elbow to elbow with laptops on knees. Congressmen and women waited in their seats expectantly. And in he came: Robert Mueller, the former special counsel dubbed â€œAmericaâ€™s straightest arrowâ€, a man whose silent mystique was such that it took Robert De Niro to play him on TV.This packed committee room on Capitol Hill, with its high ceiling, wood panelled back wall and gold-framed portraits of politicians past was, some hoped, to be the scene of Donald Trumpâ€™s downfall as Mueller talked through his report on Russian election meddling, point by devastating point. â€œWe want Bob Mueller to bring it to life,â€ the House intelligence committee chairman, Adam Schiff, had said.But once Wednesdayâ€™s seven-hour House committee hearings got under way, the welcoming smiles froze on Democratic faces, like a theatre audience realising they bought expensive tickets to the wrong show. It slowly dawned that Mueller was neither going to offer a pugnacious defence of his findings nor bring them into focus for the American public with piercing clarity. Instead the 74-year-old struggled, asking for questions to be repeated, laboriously looking up page references and offering halting, monosyllabic answers.Invited to deliver punchlines, he pulled his punches instead. When the New York congressman Hakeem Jeffries delivered a stirring soliloquy about defining obstruction of justice â€“ â€œThis is the United States of America! No one is above the law. No one. The president must be held accountable one way or the otherâ€ â€“ and looked to Mueller for affirmation, the former FBI director replied: â€œLet me â€“ let me just say I, if I might: I donâ€™t subscribe necessarily to your â€“ the way you analyse that. Iâ€™m not saying itâ€™s out of the ballpark, but Iâ€™m not supportive of that analytical charge.â€Soon enough the reviews were in: far from bringing the report to life, it was a dying fall, one that revealed Mueller to be a mere mortal after all. The backlash was swift.Comedian Bill Maher wrote on Twitter: â€œI canâ€™t watch this anymore. Go home, guys. You made OJ try on the glove, and it just didnâ€™t work. You can still win the election, but I wouldnâ€™t bet my own money on it.â€Michael Moore, the Oscar-winning documentary film-maker, tweeted: â€œA frail old man, unable to remember things, stumbling, refusing to answer basic questions...I said it in 2017 and Mueller confirmed it today â€” All you pundits and moderates and lame Dems who told the public to put their faith in the esteemed Robert Mueller â€” just STFU from now on.â€What went wrong? Why did Democrats not realise that Mueller would not only be a unwilling witness but seemingly unversed in his own report? And was it, as Republicans gleefully claimed, the kiss of death to both the Russia investigation and demands for Trumpâ€™s impeachment?Some of it was predictable. The former special counsel had cautioned in advance that he had no intention of embellishing the report he published three months ago. Bill Galston, a former policy adviser to Bill Clinton, said: â€œMr Mueller made his intentions crystal clear. He was not there to be a player in anyoneâ€™s movie. The Democrats may have thought they had little to lose and that Mr Mueller may be goaded by the more pugnacious Republicans into a moment that would go viral.â€Some of it was a shock. The Washington Post reported: â€œMany felt blindsided that no one warned them how much Mueller had aged â€“ and regretful that they had forced a decorated Vietnam veteran and longtime civil servant into testifying when he was so reluctant in the first place.â€The perceived flop left some suggesting that Democrats are now flogging a dead horse and should change direction. The New York congressman Anthony Brindisi told the Post on Thursday: â€œAnyone who was looking for the smoking gun yesterday didnâ€™t get it. Itâ€™s time to move on and focus on getting some bills passed here that can get signed into law.â€But Democratic leaders argue there is a principle at stake. It is their constitutional duty, they say, to chase down every lead in the Mueller report, call more witnesses and put it all before the public. Failure to do so would imply that Trump is above the law and set the worst possible example for future presidents.At a press conference, the Maryland congressman Elijah Cummings spoke passionately about the big picture: â€œMartin Luther King said â€¦ â€˜There comes a point when silence becomes betrayal.â€™ And we refuse to betray generations yet unborn and the American people. Weâ€™re not going to betray them. Weâ€™re accumulating information and doing the best we can â€¦ Weâ€™re going to do our part to make sure that we have a democracy thatâ€™s intact.â€To that end, the hearings did enable Mueller to refute, on camera, Trumpâ€™s claim that Russian meddling is a â€œhoaxâ€, that the investigation was a â€œwitch-huntâ€ or that it gave him â€œtotal exonerationâ€. In rare expressions of opinion, Mueller described Trumpâ€™s praise of WikiLeaks as â€œproblematicâ€ and gravely warned that Russia will continue to attack US democracy. Future historians may judge the transcripts damning for the president.Nearly a hundred House Democrats favour impeachment and presumably hoped that Muellerâ€™s testimony would be a game-changer. But Shrum said: â€œI think Wednesday sent a clear signal thatâ€™s not the way to go. The president would do everything to resist, put up roadblocks and challenge it in court. I think the best way to defeat him is at the ballot box. At this point impeachment is a distraction.â€Wendy Schiller, a political science professor at Brown University in Providence, Rhode Island, said: â€œMuellerâ€™s lacklustre testimony likely gave Speaker Pelosi the ammunition to withstand calls for impeachment inquiries, or hearings, from the left flank of her party. She has always maintained it is a losing political proposition even if the House voted to impeach Trump because the Senate will not vote to convict Trump and remove him from office.â€Although Mueller did not generate enough sound bites to be used across media platforms in the election campaign, Schiller added, â€œthe lurking danger for Trump is that among independent voters, who leaned toward him in 2016, there is discomfort with the way he conducts himself.â€œFor now, the strong economy is insulating Trump against that discomfort, but any downturn in the economy next summer or in fall 2020 might lead those voters to either stay home, or vote for someone other than Trump. And in some swing states, that could be enough to cost him the election.â€The Democrats seeking the presidency have been talking about healthcare, economic inequality and racial injustice and saying much less about Mueller or impeachment on the campaign trail.Galston, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution thinktank, said: â€œI think the candidates on the stump are being politically realistic the people back in Washington arenâ€™t. Nancy Pelosi, who is a wintry eyed realist, is having none of it: she thinks impeachment is a foolsâ€™ errand and I have to say I agree with her.â€

title: morbidly sensible adulting no way getting life insurance is empowering
story: Does the thought of tackling life insurance send you into a slumber? Hereâ€™s why it could be worth giving it another shot â€¦TV, takeaways and, erm, life insurance â€“ I know which Iâ€™d rather commit to tonight when I get home. Admittedly, insurance isnâ€™t exactly the sexiest of weeknight propositions, so itâ€™s hardly any wonder so many of us choose to bury our heads in the proverbial sand when it comes to facing it. But before you fall into a slumber deeper than Snow White on a hangover, let me tell you why it might be worth giving it five minutes of your time (it wonâ€™t take any longer than that, promise).You see, life insurance is one of those things that makes perfect sense on paper - the kind of task you wonder why you didnâ€™t get round to sorting once you realise what it actually involves (before swiftly ignoring it again for another six months, if youâ€™re anything like me). I mean, think about it, how many important things have you taken the time to insure in your lifetime? I can name several - a car, the odd holiday, my home and a smartphone (or six). So why is it weâ€™re neglecting to insure the most important thing of all?A quick straw poll of my friends reveals the many reasons we donâ€™t. Some figure that not having children, a partner, or owning a home, means they donâ€™t need it â€“ they reason thereâ€™s no point spending money on something they donâ€™t actually need yet. But if either of those things could plausibly happen in the near future, it might be worth planning ahead (after all, youâ€™ll have more pressing things to worry about once any #wedmin kicks in, and doing it sooner likely means lower monthly payments, too). Itâ€™s also worth asking whether any dependants or loved ones would be financially stable without you, since life insurance could take care of that (something not many of us like to think about, granted).Life insurance could also be very useful for anybody jointly responsible for mortgage payments. What happens if one person dies before the mortgage is paid (nope, not a fun discussion but an important one)? Experts flag that we shouldnâ€™t assume death-in-service cover or life insurance via your employer means we donâ€™t need to worry about life insurance, either, unfortunately. While useful, workplace cover tends to pay out benefits as a multiple of salary (eg four-yearsâ€™ salary) to ensure your family has cash available to make up for the loss of your salary to maintain their lifestyle it may not cover any large financial commitments, such as a mortgage.What are the available options? Well, Aviva offers three types of life insurance: cover that remains the same, and so do the payments cover and premiums that increase over time and cover that decreases.For the latter, the value of the cover goes down each month, but your regular payments stay the same. People usually use this product to cover a repayment mortgage, which also decreases.If youâ€™re looking to help cover your salary and maintain loved onesâ€™ living standards or to settle your mortgage and provide reassurance â€“ then you may want to go for the same level, or increasing if you want some protection against the effects of inflation. Still with me? Good.The best part is thereâ€™s minimal legwork â€“ most customers could get a quote and decision in just over five minutes (reading this is probably the most arduous part, sorry) and it might be cheaper than you think, with policies starting at around Â£5 a month. So we could all start protecting our loved ones immediately.Pretty awesome, right? And probably much smarter than putting it off until your next birthday, and spending more when we do bite the bullet (since policies tend to get more expensive the older you are). Making that decision suddenly feels like a no-brainer to me â€“ what about you? Then we can all get back to that boxset and tikka masala â€¦For more information, visit avivalife

title: the world knows what is happening to the uighurs why has it been so slow to act
story: A reluctance to offend China and an information blackout has meant the persecution of the ethnic minority has gone under the radar. But pressure for change is building On Wednesday, Sadam Abdusalam went to Australiaâ€™s federal Parliament House for the first time and spent almost 12 hours meeting politicians â€“ meetings he has spent almost two years hoping for â€“ in which he pleaded for their help to bring his wife and nearly two-year-old son home.Last week Abdusalamâ€™s story was broadcast on Four Corners, detailing how his wife and son are trapped in China because they are Uighurs â€“ ethnic minority Muslims.It was not the first time he had told his story publicly â€“ he first did so to Buzzfeed in February, and then to  Australia in April, when  Australia revealed there were at least five Australian children trapped in China due to the countryâ€™s increasingly brutal crackdown on Uighur people in the far-west region of Xinjiang.But it was the first time Abdusalam had revealed his identity, and feels as though things might finally be shifting for his family. He hopes his wife and son might soon be able to come to Australia â€“ ideally in time for his sonâ€™s second birthday on 31 August â€“ meaning he could meet his son for the first time.While Abdusalam is grateful for the support the government is showing his family now, he says on his recent trip to Canberra he struggled with a question the entire Uighur community is grappling with.â€œI wanted to tell them: â€˜Where have you been the last few years?â€™â€It is almost a year since the United Nations reported that an estimated one million people, mostly Uighurs, were being held in detention centres across Xinjiang and urged China to release them.Even before then, there were regular reports that Uighurs were subject to extraordinary surveillance, required to give blood, DNA and biometric face scans, forced to hand over their passports, denied permission to leave Xinjiang and detained in huge numbers. China has finally been forced to admit the detention centres exist, but still insists they are â€œvocational training centresâ€. Uighurs may be held there for crimes such as having a beard, having a Muslim name, having WhatsApp on their phone, having family members who live abroad, or for no apparent reason at all.But it was only two weeks ago that a statement was issued by 22 countries condemning Chinaâ€™s treatment of Uighur and other minorities. So why has it taken so long for the world to care about the plight of the Uighurs?â€œIt has been taking a surprisingly long time,â€ says Nury Turkel, chairman of the Uyghur Human Rights Project in Washington. â€œThere are a couple of reasons: one is obviously the China factor. Itâ€™s a big country, kind of a reckless country, governments are often very careful to take a stand.â€James Leibold, an associate professor in politics and Asian studies at Melbourneâ€™s La Trobe University, says Chinaâ€™s economic clout and other countriesâ€™ reluctance to rock the trade boat is clearly a factor, but there are others. Most people in the west have not heard of Uighurs or Xinjiang â€“ a very remote part of China â€“ and awareness of their plight has not been championed by a figure well-known in the west, as the Tibetan situation was by the Dalai Lama.Then there is the difficulty in getting information out of Xinjiang. China has restricted access to foreign journalists, other than those taken on bizarre propaganda tours, so reporters have largely been left to rely on accounts of escapees and the diaspora as well as satellite imagery to try to piece together what is going on there.â€œThe informational warfare thatâ€™s occurring at present â€¦ gives cover to governments or allows governments not to respond because they will say: â€˜We donâ€™t really know whatâ€™s happeningâ€™,â€ says Leibold.China has exacted severe retribution against those who have spoken out, including Abdusalamâ€™s wife who, since the Four Corners broadcast, has been taken in by police almost every day and questioned for three or four hours.â€œThey have been telling her to tell me to keep my mouth shut,â€ says Abdusalam. â€œSheâ€™s really frightened.â€â€œNo one wants to talk, with good reason,â€ says Leibold.China has also walked a â€œvery deliberate and very carefulâ€ line in committing serious human rights abuses without perpetrating the sort of physical violence that might attract widespread global condemnation, says Elaine Pearson, the Australia director of Human Rights Watch.â€œI think part of the reason this is under the radar is that people arenâ€™t overtly being killed or raped or tortured.â€ Despite this, Pearson says what China is doing in Xinjiang is â€œabsolutely terrifyingâ€.â€œThey are blueprinting a way of eradicating Muslim identity from a population and I think thatâ€™s something we should all be quite scared about.â€œWe spend so much time and energy on this religious freedom debate in Australia well hereâ€™s a group of people that are about to be exterminated in terms of their religion,â€ says Pearson.Leibold says a â€œsubtle, unarticulated bias against Islamâ€ may also go some way to explain why the â€œslow-burning act of cultural genocideâ€ in Xinjiang has not gained traction in western countries.â€œMuslims unfortunately have very little sympathy globally at the moment. There is this spectre of Islamophobia globally that sits behind this issue,â€ says Leibold.Turkel believes things have shifted in recent months. In Washington DC, where he is based, there is momentum for legislation enforcing targeted sanctions at senior Chinese officials.But Australia could do more, he says. â€œI would like to see the Australian government be a little more steady and outspoken,â€ he says, particularly in light of the five Australian children, including Abdusalamâ€™s, who are trapped in Xinjiang, unable to return home to their Australian parents.â€œIt should keep Australian politicians awake at night.â€

title: jacob rees mogg esq releases set of rules to new staff
story: Leader of the House of Commons Jacob Rees-Mogg (C) speaking in the Houses of Parliament flanked by Britainâ€™s Prime Minister Boris Johnson (L) and Britainâ€™s Chancellor of the Exchequer Sajid Javid. Photograph: Jessica TaylorUK ParliamentAFPGetty ImagesLeader of the House of Commons Jacob Rees-Mogg has issued a set of rules for staff in his office to follow, including a list of banned words and a requirement to use imperial measurements.Mr Rees-Mogg, who was brought into the government by Boris Johnson on Wednesday, wasted little time in issuing the guidance to staff.According to the style guide obtained by ITV News, Mr Rees-Mogg insists that all non-titled males are given the suffix Esq- short for Esquire - and says words including â€œongoingâ€ and â€œhopefullyâ€ are banned.In a call for accuracy, he tells staff: â€œCHECK your work.â€The guidance was drawn up by Mr Rees-Moggâ€™s North East Somerset constituency team some years ago, but has now been shared with officials in his new office.Other directions include a call for a double space after full stops and no comma after the word â€œandâ€.He also set out a series of banned words and phrases that should not be used by his staff.They include: very, due to, unacceptable, equal, yourself, lot, got, speculate, meet with, ascertain and disappointment.Staff should avoid â€œtoo many â€˜Isâ€™â€ in their writing, Mr Rees-Mogg will not be â€œpleased to learnâ€ anything, he will not â€œnoteunderstand your concernsâ€ nor will he â€œinvest (in schools etc)â€, and the phrase â€œno longer fit for purposeâ€ has been deemed no longer fit for purpose.As chair of the European Research Group - an influential, hard-Brexit Conservative backbench grouping - Mr Rees-Mogg has increased his influence in Westminster in recent years. The official transcript of parliamentary proceedings, Hansard, records more than 700 instances of Mr Rees-Mogg using one or other of the banned words or phrases. He is an Old Etonian, like the prime minister he serves, and, like the prime minister he serves, has cultivated a reputation for formality and upper-class eccentricity, gaining the nickname the â€œhonourable member for the 18th centuryâ€. When standing for the Conservatives for the Central Fife seat in 1997, he took his nanny and his motherâ€™s Mercedes out canvassing. Mr Rees-Mogg has also used his position of influence to argue against abortion, even in cases of rape, and same-sex marriage. He has been one of the most prominent backers of a hard Brexit and, last year, it was revealed that a City firm he co-founded had set up an investment fund in Ireland and was warning prospective clients about the financial dangers of a hard Brexit. Following his appointment by Mr Johnson this week, he is responsible for organising government business in the Commons.The Commons Leaderâ€™s office would not comment on the leaked document.Deal or No Deal: countdown to Brexit continues as the deadline for crashing out of Europe fast approaches. story: A French inventorâ€™s daring attempt to cross the Channel on his jet-powered hoverboard ended in a disappointing splash when he fell into the water while trying to refuel half way across.Franky Zapata, 40, lost his balance when he attempted to land on a platformÂ on a boat to change his backpack, which contained 42 litres of kerosene when he took off from a beach in Sangatte, near the northern French port of Calais. He had flown for 11 miles at speeds of up to 87 mph, 50 feet above the waves.Divers from the refuelling boat pulled him out of the water unhurt with his â€˜Flyboardâ€™, which he designed and built himself.StÃ©phane Denis, a member of Mr Zapataâ€™s support team, said: â€œIt is a huge disappointment. That threw him off balance and he fell into the water.â€ Mr Denis added that he would make another attempt, probably within weeks. title: thou shalt not take lords name vain italian town issue 400 blasphemy
story: The city council of Saonara has made it illegal â€œto blaspheme against any faith or religionâ€A northern Italian town has had enough of people taking the Lordâ€™s name in vain and those who do will be fined up to â‚¬400 (Â£360) for blasphemy.The city council of Saonara, a town with 10,000 inhabitants just outside Padua, has introduced a new law making it illegal â€œto blaspheme against any faith or religionâ€ and utter foul language in public.The mayor, Walter Stefan, said the move was designed to get rid of uncivilised behaviour and promote public decency.â€œBlasphemy is offensive, it offends me,â€ Mr Stefan told The  on Friday.â€œWith this law you will not be able to cause offence to any religion, we have to respect the faithful.â€The mayor, a practicing Catholic, said it was not designed to protect only Christianity, but all faiths. â€œIt is valid for Allah, Buddha or Mohammad,â€ he said.The blasphemy ban is part of a far-reaching local law aimed at tackling uncivil behaviour. It includes 75 articles with hefty sanctions for those who mow the lawn outside designated hours, walk their dog without a leash or dump their rubbish in public places.â€œWe have taken a series of measures to contain all those uncivilised activities that make coexistence difficult,â€ Mr Stefan said.â€œIt will no longer be possible to cut the lawn at certain times, dogs must be kept on a leash and those who are blasphemous will pay the consequences.â€œWe want to send a message that incorrect behaviour will no longer be tolerated.â€Mr Stefan, a father of three, is not aligned with any major political party and has been mayor of the town since 2012. He was re-elected in 2017 with 52.2 percent of the vote.He said flyers in four languages, including Chinese and Romanian, would be sent to residents in September to inform them about the new fines.â€œThere may be bigger problems around but we canâ€™t consider civility banal, he said. If we let this go, young people will become louts.â€œWe want to create a courteous community and behaviour that prevents conflict.â€Omero Badon, a local councillor from the Five Star Movement, said he supported the law but did not know if the fines would be enough to improve behaviour, especially that of young people, in the community.Blasphemy was decriminalised in Italy in 1999 but certain sanctions remain for offences against the â€œdeityâ€.Â  In December last year a man was fined â‚¬100 for blasphemy in front of a school in Albisola Superiore near Savona.US Supreme Court allows Trump
