Its kit can be found in just about every Airbus jet, for example.&nbspFootasylum could run a lot faster under JDâ€™s wing after Â£90m takeoverCobham hit by US defence spending cutsAdventâ€™s offer represents a 34 per cent premium over Wednesdayâ€™s closing share price, and it looks like a shoo-in to get the 75 per cent support from shareholders that&nbspit requires for the deal to go through.The premium looks like a tasty one, and the majority of its investors will likely sign up in a heartbeat.&nbspFor a start, the board has backed it unanimously, as has Artemis, one of&nbspits bigger institutional shareholders. While the company has found its feet of late, its recent history has not been entirely happy. It issued a string of profit warnings between 2015 and 2017. In the last of those years it tapped shareholders for an emergency Â£500m to help with a debt-mountain built up in part through a botched acquisition.&nbspThe new shares, issued through the cash call, were priced at 75p. Investors who signed up and held on to them are getting 165p in cash from Advent. Cha-ching.&nbspCould Cobham have got there on its own, though? The shares were at a higher level than that as recently as the beginning of 2016. It might seem like a tall order given Britainâ€™s desperate political climate, but the question is rarely asked even when things are going well. The rule in the City is you take the money and run when itâ€™s offered. &nbspAnother rarely raised question, unless the company involved is a big household name, is whether the deal is a good one for this country.&nbspIn the case of Cobham, the government may not even need to lie about this being an investment in Britain that shows off its vim.&nbspAdvent has surely been assisted by the climate that government has created. Its behaviour has so tarnished Sterling that shares denominated in the UKâ€™s currency are unnaturally cheap for overseas bidders, which can therefore afford to make their offers look generous.&nbspWith the requirement to act like a good little vassal of the US, any muted objections to the deal will fall on deaf ears. longer allow customers with its FlexPlus account a Â£250 overdraft without charges.The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has banned daily fees on overdrafts, requiring lenders to charge through an Company results usually come out at 7am, but by 8am on Friday, when the stock market opened, the results were still missing, all planned calls with the media and analysts were cancelled and a presentation to investors at the retailerâ€™s London head office was scrapped.A spokesman for Sports Direct said: â€œUnfortunately we are still finalising preliminary results. We anticipate that our annual results will still be released today, with a presentation to follow.â€The company then issued updates at midday and 2pm, each time saying it was still finalising the report. The latest update is due at 4pm.&nbspSports Direct shares seesawed during the day, falling in response to every update from the company. There were odes to Humphrey Bogart (â€œ2HBâ€) and cyber-rock jams (â€œLadytronâ€), and songs decorated with spooky-sounding hooks that wouldnâ€™t sound out of place in The Rocky Horror Show (the character Riff Raff even seemed to take his cues from a balding Brian Eno).Still regarded by many as his greatest album to date, Reasonable Doubt asserted Jay-Z as a master freestyle â€“ perhaps the best of his generation â€“ recorded in a studio he compared to a psychiatristâ€™s couch. At the heart of the record is a blistering duet with the Notorious BIG, â€œBrooklynâ€™s Finestâ€, which practically heralded the shift of focus back from West Coast hip hop to the East.Rolling Stone's Lester Bangs described the Black Sabbath as â€œjust like Cream! But worseâ€, and their debut album as â€œa shuck â€“ despite the murky song titles and some inane lyrics that sound like Vanilla Fudge paying doggerel tribute to Aleister Crowley, the album has nothing to do with spiritualism, the occult, or anything much except stiff recitations of Cream clichÃ©sâ€. The Village Voice werenâ€™t keen either, with critic Robert Christgau condemning it as â€œbulls**t necromancy.â€ Yet this is the album that invented heavy metal. Black Sabbath arrived ready to lure fans over to the dark side with Ozzy Osbourneâ€™s piercing, operatic cry: â€œMy name is Lucifer, please take my hand.â€ Critics be damned.1835 18) Sex Pistols â€“ Never Mind the Bollocks, Here's the Sex Pistols (1977)â€œThe album will last. The sleeve may not,â€ said the adverts for the Sex Pistolsâ€™ first and only studio album in 1977. The Sex Pistols were already controversial before the release of Never Mind the Bollocks, having caused nationwide uproar for swearing on live TV, been fired from two record labels, and been banned from a number of live venues in England. Yet despite many major retailers refusing to sell it, the album debuted at number one on the UK album charts and is today regarded as one of the most important punk albums in music history.Joe Strummer was a ball of rage and ambition when he and the rest of The Clash laid down the tracks for their debut album. Most of the guitar on this record was provided by Mick Jones, because Strummer didnâ€™t think technical ability was punk enough. Yet their vision burns through on the buzz-saw attack of â€œCareer Opportunitiesâ€ and â€œWhite Riotâ€, raising a fist against unemployment, racism and the fat cats of industry. 2035 16) Guns N Roses â€“ Appetite for Destruction (1987)Guns N Roses' Appetite for Destruction was the biggest thing to happen to hard rock since Led Zeppelin IV. Slashâ€™s guitar and Axl Roseâ€™s wild, animal howls contribute to the raw energy on songs like â€œParadise Cityâ€ and marked a dramatic shift away from the commercialised heavy rock that was being played on MTV at the time â€“ proudly championing a gritty form of hedonism instead. â€œA lot of rock bands are too f***ing wimpy to have any sentiment or emotion,â€ Rose said. Not this band.Daft Punk's Homework was originally intended as â€œjust a load of singlesâ€, until Thomas Bangalter and Guy-Manuel de Homem-Christo realised they had enough quality tracks for a full-length release. Each one opens with a kind of motif upon which multiple textures build and sprawl outwards â€“ sleazy guitar hooks, G-funk whines and glittering synths. Itâ€™s the album that alerted the rest of the world to the French house music scene.Sex and poetry go hand in hand, especially if youâ€™re a Jim Morrison fan. While few bands manage to ide critical opinion as much as The Doors, their debut albumâ€™s organ-driven rock was as tight as their frontmanâ€™s famous leather trousers. They brought theatricality to the Sixties music scene and went onto inspire as broad a range of artists as The Stranglers to Skrillex. The baroque pop stylings and lustful lyrics on â€œLight My Fireâ€ proved to be a breakthrough, and helped propel them to number two on the US Billboard 200.After making a name for himself on Jay-Zâ€™s The Blueprint as well as by producing hits for Janet Jackson and Ludacris, Kanye West spent four years recording The College Dropout. His background as a producer was obviously beneficial to his own debut, at a time where hip hop sampling was being accused of being too safe. And he subverted many other hip hop clichÃ©s, skirting round the dominant â€œgangstaâ€ persona and instead finding solace in family and the church.2435 12) Pink Floyd â€“ The Piper at the Gates of Dawn (1967)Pink Floydâ€™s debut The Piper at the Gates of Dawn stands as a classic of psychedelic rock. Helmed by an unravelling Syd Barrett â€“ ousted a year after the albumâ€™s release â€“ it shows the band at their most playful, with several tracks going onto become staples of their live shows. Songs such as â€œBikeâ€, meanwhile, proved the band were not averse to a good pop hook along with the acid guitars and hazy production. 2535 11) Lauryn Hill â€“ The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill (1998)Lauryn Hill raised the game for an entire genre with the immense and groundbreaking record, The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill. Flipping between two tones â€“ sharp and cold, and sensual and smoky â€“ the former Fugees member stepped out from rapâ€™s misogynist status quo and drew an audience outside of hip hop thanks to her melding of soul, reggae and R&ampB, and the recruitment of the likes of Mary J Blige and Dâ€™Angelo. Its sonic appeal has a lot to do with the lo-fi production and warm instrumentation, often comprised of a low thrumming bass, tight snares and doo-wop harmonies. But Hillâ€™s reggae influences are what drive the albumâ€™s spirit: preaching love and peace but also speaking out against unrighteous oppression. Even today, itâ€™s one of the most uplifting and inspiring records around.2635 10) Dizzee Rascal â€“ Boy in Da Corner (2003)Itâ€™s staggering to listen back to Boy in Da Corner and remember Dizzee Rascal was just 18-years-old when he released it. Rising through the UK garage scene as a member of east Londonâ€™s Roll Deep crew, the MC born Dylan Mills allegedly honed his skills in production after being excluded from every one of his classes, apart from music. If you want any sense of how ahead of the game Dizzee was, just listen to the opening track â€œSittinâ€™ Hereâ€. While 2018 has suffered a spate of half-hearted singles playing on the listenerâ€™s sense of nostalgia for simpler times, 15 years ago Dizzee longed for the innocence of childhood because of what he was seeing in the present day: teenage pregnancies, police brutality, his friends murdered on the streets or lost to a lifestyle of crime and cash. Boy in da Corner goes heavy on cold, uncomfortably disjointed beats, synths that emulate arcade games and police sirens, and Dizzee himself delivering bars in his trademark, high-pitched squawk.2735 9) Beastie Boys â€“ Licensed to Ill (1986)Hip hopâ€™s first number one album was an incendiary, all-guns-blazing record that would send shockwaves around the music industry for years to come. Few artists release something so assertive as this â€“ a statement of intent to middle America that demanded they fight for their right to party. Beastie Boys' Mike D, Ad-Rock and MCA would move on from the frat boy humour and â€œgood timeâ€ attitude of Licensed to Ill, but it is that record that delivered rap against a backdrop of Led Zeppelin and James Brown-inspired guitar licks.2835 8) The Notorious BIG â€“ Ready to Die (1994)The rapper Notorious BIG, born Christopher Wallace, had been taking part in rap battles around Fulton Street, Brooklyn since he was 13 years old, but it was only at the urging of his friends that he quit a lucrative drugs operation and devoted himself to music. Living on a knifeâ€™s edge was all Biggie Smalls knew as a kid, when he was â€œwaking up every morning, hustling, cutting school, looking out for my moms, the police, stickup kids just risking my life every day on the street selling drugsâ€, as he told Rolling Stone back in 1995. The things he witnessed and experienced were poured into Ready to Die â€“ one of the best debut albums in hip hop â€“ delivered in his signature throaty vocals with wit and humour.At less than 30 minutes, Ramonesâ€™ debut injects their rage, their disillusionment and their frustration directly into the listenerâ€™s veins. Itâ€™s a record that spurned the posturing of Seventies rock and stripped all of the artifice away to the bare bones beneath, with songs such as â€œBeat on the Bratâ€ and â€œNow I Wanna Sniff Some Glueâ€ proving to be as surly as the band themselves. â€œOur early songs came out of our real feelings of alienation, isolation, frustration â€“ the feelings everybody feels between seventeen and seventy-five,â€ singer Joey Ramone said. The whole record cost just $6,000 to make.NWA unveiled their cold, menacing sound on debut record Straight Outta Compton that heralded the beginning of gangsta rap and also launched the careers of Dr Dre, Eazy-E and Ice Cube. The latter made it clear they werenâ€™t positioning themselves as people to look up to: â€œDo I look like a mother***ing role mode?â€ he demands on â€œGangsta Gangstaâ€. Their track â€œF*** tha Policeâ€ â€“ a protest track against racism and police brutality â€“ led to them receiving a threatening letter from the FBI, which only contributed to their growing fame.Dubbed the Banana Album for its famous Andy Warhol cover art, The Velvet Underground &amp Nico is proof of what a band can do when they are completely fearless. With Nico â€“ the beautiful German vocalist added to the band at Warholâ€™s request â€“ you have this exquisite balance of cool femininity and fiery machismo. Sex and hedonism are everywhere on this record, from â€œVenus in Fursâ€ to â€œRun Run Runâ€, but itâ€™s not so much glamour as glam rock â€“ gritty tales of drug addiction and raw desire. Speaking of its initially low sales figures, Brian Eno observed that, nonetheless, â€œeveryone who bought one of those 30,000 copies started a bandâ€. David Bowie called it â€œthe future of musicâ€, and 52 years later, it still feels like it.A virtual unknown to rock fans just a year before â€“ Jimi Hendrix used Are You Experienced  to assert himself as a guitar genius who could combine pop, blues, rock, R&ampB, funk and psychedelia in a way no other artist had before. Thatâ€™s even without the essential contributions of drummer Mitch Mitchell and bassist Noel Redding, who handed Are You Experienced the rhythmic bridge between jazz and rock. Few album openers are as exquisite as â€œPurple Hazeâ€. Few tracks are as gratifying, as sexy, as the strut on â€œFoxy Ladyâ€.  And few songs come close to the existential bliss caused by â€œThe Wind Cries Maryâ€. Hendrixâ€™s attack on the guitar contrasted against the more polished virtuosos in rock at the time â€“ yet it is his raw ferocity that we find ourselves coming back to. Few debuts have changed the course of rock music as Hendrix did with his.â€œJesus died for somebodyâ€™s sins, but not mine,â€ go the immortal opening words of Patti Smithâ€™s debut album Horses. Thereâ€™s a heady anticipation as she speaks the lyric in a low, seductive murmur, before switching to a cocky swagger as the electric guitar line kicks in. It was a bold move, to open her debut album with a reinvention of someone elseâ€™s song (in this case Van Morrisonâ€™s â€œGloriaâ€), but Smith was unlike anything the music world had ever seen. She was a poet, who wanted to capture the literary genius of her idol Arthur Rimbaud and channel it via the raw passion of an artist like Jimi Hendrix. â€œShe was like a wildcat, walking out with this jacket slung over her shoulder,â€ Sonic Youthâ€™s Thurston Moore once recalled of seeing her perform the album live in 1976. â€œIt was life-changing.â€How good can rap get? This good. There are albums where the myth can transcend the music not on Illmatic, where Nas vaulted himself into the ranks of the greatest MCs in 1994, with an album that countless artists since have tried â€“ and failed â€“ to emulate. Enlisting the hottest producers around â€“ Pete Rock, DJ Premier, Q-Tip, L.E.S and Large Professor â€“ was a move that Complex blamed for â€œruining hip hopâ€, while still praising Nasâ€™s record, because it had a lasting impact on the use of multiple producers on rap albums. Nas used the sounds of the densley-populated New York streets he grew up on. You hear the rattle of the steel train that opens the record, along with the cassette tape hissing the verse from a teenage Nasty Nas on Main Sourceâ€™s 1991 track â€œLive at the BBQâ€: â€˜When I was 12, I went to Hell for snuffing Jesus.â€Unknown Pleasures is unlike any album that had been created before it â€“ or indeed any album since. Itâ€™s mysteriousness makes it as compelling as many great works of literature indeed, our critic Chris Harvey said the spiritual force emanating from the Joy Division's record's grooves make it feel â€œalmost Dostoevskyanâ€. Peter Hookâ€™s basslines veer and thrum wildly beneath Ian Curtisâ€™s dark mutterings that are at once urgent, detached, and strangely sexless. On â€œSheâ€™s Lost Controlâ€ it as though youâ€™re hearing the band play from the end of a dark tunnel â€“ the echoes of Curtis's voice and the ominous rumblings of that bass build and build. By the time you reach those final, shivery notes on â€œI Remember Nothingâ€, it doesnâ€™t feel like an overstatement to call this a life-changing record.Some fans have been waiting up for six&nbsphours to hear the new album.Other have been speculating that Kanye Westâ€™s involvement in the album could have led to its delay, given his reputation as a perfectionist.Chance the Rapper has been teasing the release of his new material on Twitter for weeks, writing â€œthe day is on its wayâ€ and announcing a Spotify launch party which took place on Thursday night.The best in film, music, TV &amp radio straight to your inboxThe best in film, music, TV &amp radio straight to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: papua new guinea kabakon island beach castaway travel
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsCreated with Sketch.Ready to strip himself of anything, and everything, remotely&nbspconnected to the 21st century, Safi Thind travels to a derelict island for five days, and uncovers more secrets â€“ and ghosts â€“ than he&nbspbargained forClick to followThe IndependentPalm fronds bending in the breeze. The sun beating down. No one around for miles. We all have our desert island fantasies. How might you fare marooned on a strange land? Could you fend for yourself? In the spirit of Robinson Crusoe, Iâ€™ve decided to spend five days castaway on an uninhabited island in the south Pacific.&nbspThe place is Kabakon, one of Papua New Guineaâ€™s 13 Duke of York islands, 800km east of the capital Port Moresby. It is owned by the tribe who live on the neighbouring island of Karawara, who use it as their garden.A hotel on the mainland sets up the basics for me but, to all extents and purposes, it is a term of solitary confinement. Just me and my flimsy penknife. Bouncing over the waves to the island, we pass the steaming volcano Tavurvur, a startling reminder that Iâ€™m slap bang on&nbspthe Pacific ring of fire.&nbspThen we run into a pod of frolicking dolphins, which&nbspskip along with the boat like theyâ€™re old friends. Itâ€™s a cheery omen for the adventure ahead.After about 45 minutes,&nbspKabakon&nbspheaves into view.The island is&nbsp80 hectares of white sand, fringed with palms and blue water, and is as close to a paradisiacal idyll as I have ever seen. Thereâ€™s no luxury here. Iâ€™m staying in a two-roomed shack with a mattress on the floor, mosquito net, and some chairs and a table on the veranda. The hotel has provided basic food â€“ bread, dried noodles, fruit and a few tins. Thereâ€™s no wifi or TV&nbspno signs of digital life. Nothing to tie me to the world outside.Showing me the ropes is Corey Eron, councillor of Karawara, and the brainchild of the trip. He wants to encourage tourism to the island to help the village economy. He is an idealist but practical with it and charismatic to boot. His dreads shake with mirth as his infectious laughter punctuates the conversation. You can see why the islanders hold him in high regard, voting him their council representative every year for the past seven.&nbspHeâ€™ll keep me company some of the time but Iâ€™ve told him I need to do this alone.&nbspMy first task is to explore the island. My shack faces Karawara in the east with the mountains of New Ireland shimmering dimly in the distance. The side Iâ€™m on is beach and sand while the other is tall rocky cliffs that block the battering encroachment of the sea. Inland is thick vegetation and the Karawaran garden. I determine to walk around the island, which should take two to three hoursâ€¦&nbspprobably.A guy stops on the path and pulls out some betel nuts and lime powder from his bag, which I chew, turning my lips red. Iâ€™m invited to eat taro (root) and freshly cooked fish stew. And Iâ€™m offered homebrewKabakon is filled with curious life. Blue and red starfish and sea cucumbers bask in the water, little darting fish weave between your toes. Inland, there are red-beaked parrots, multicoloured lizards and black and white willie wagtail birds with their absurd rear-end movement like theyâ€™re doing the twist. The plant life is equally fascinating. Spiky pandanus palms and coconuts dominate but there is also a single huge banyan tree, the tallest on the island and for miles around, with roots hanging like thick dark ropes from the trunk. As Iâ€™m walking along, I come across a sudden bloom of colourful flowers and weeping willow trees, which seem incongruous in their surroundings.In fact, this is part of Kabakonâ€™s strange history.&nbspIn 1902, the island was bought by one August&nbspEngelhardt, a 26-year-old German, who was looking for somewhere to develop his utopian philosophy based on principles of sun worship and cocovorism&nbspâ€“ the notion that eating nothing but coconuts is key to solving manâ€™s physical ailments. Heâ€™d come into a substantial inheritance and purchased Kabakon for his new Eden.The first few years were idyllic. Engelhardt established a coconut plantation and called his followers to join&nbsphim in this brave new world. They called themselves Sonnenorden and practised sun worship and nudity and lived off coconuts. But it didnâ€™t last. The alien living conditions took their toll and several died. Others turned their back on him. Engelhardt was eventually left alone, was gripped by malaria and&nbspwent insane. He died aged 46 and was rumoured to have been&nbspburied on the neighbouring island of Mioko, though his grave was never found.The ghost of this eccentric man occupies me as I weave my way around the island, but progress is hard. The vegetation is thick and my path is blocked by tall plants draped in spiderwebs, while the cliffs prevent me walking along the water. Eventually, I decide to turn inland, where I stumble upon the village plantations.The island garden is a beautiful sight. Immaculately tended plots of banana and coconut trees mixed with yams, peanuts and all kinds of tropical fruit. It looks, indeed, very Edenic. But Iâ€™ve now no idea where I am or how to get back. Even as Iâ€™m thinking that I might be stuck a young face appears from the undergrowth.â€œThe beach path?â€ he asks.â€œYes,â€ I say sheepishly, trying to excuse my intrusion and wondering if I have trampled on his hard work.He gestures me to follow, then asks if Iâ€™d like to eat some singapo. Unsure what it is, I say yes â€“ in for a penny, in for a pound. He takes me up a different path where we come upon a group of boys cooking yams on a fire. One offers me the singapo: â€œCrunchy,â€ he says, while another asks if I want a kulao (green coconut). I nod and he immediately leaps on to the base of a 30ft-coconut tree and starts shimmying up using no more than a leaf harness hooked round his feet. In a flash, heâ€™s up there hacking down coconuts, suspended upside down with one hand. Madness, I think, and eat the purple, smoked yam and drink water fresh from the coconut with a new appreciation.The islanders are quick with humour and generous to a fault. Itâ€™s one of&nbspmy first lessons about&nbspthe Karawaran people. Language might be an issue but communication is easy&nbspthey are charming.Later I chat with Corey about life here. It looks like paradise but living isnâ€™t easy. The relentless march of modernity is inescapable. Customs are being eroded. The islanders used to trade exclusively with shell money (kina) but that is dying off as notes and coin currency become de facto. With coconuts and fish, the islandâ€™s only two money earners, it is harder to buy things.Corey says they are lucky to have the garden island, which provides them with food. But for everything else, they need money. Better medicine, for example â€“&nbspseven people died of malaria last year. Or school equipment, and clothes. The PNG government is well-intentioned but notoriously poor in execution. The country draws explorers and anthropologists to the fascination of a land that has over 800 languages, wild and ancient tribes and customs, some that seem truly outlandish and brutal to us. Yet the real trouble here is not the ancient customs but modern governmental mismanagement, which&nbspis unlikely to change soon.Coreyâ€™s grandmother once tasted human flesh. She told of how the tribe caught a man, tied him up, removed his eyes and turned his head around, then kept him by the fire still alive for three days while they collected sweet potatoes until finally he was thrown inCollapsed on&nbspmy mattress, Iâ€™m ready to sleep but the night brings strange noises and even stranger visitors. Things come hissing and creeping into my feverish mind. It seems to take hours until finally, hot and sweaty, Iâ€™m soothed by the sounds of the tropical rain that thrums on&nbspthe thatched roof and fall into a deep slumber.In the morning I find the table covered in delicate ant wings, their bodies seared off by the lamp I left lit overnight. It is something of a symbolic sacrifice.Waking on the second day there is a pull for the familiar. The desire for something you know, because youâ€™re stuck here in these unfamiliar surroundings. I wonder what the weather is like back home. If Boris is PM yet. Whether anyoneâ€™s missing me.&nbspI walk along the sands until I come upon a man tying crabs he caught overnight. They call him â€œSir Crabâ€ because he is a specialist in&nbspcatching them.&nbspâ€œThe crabs are clever,â€ he says, â€œso you have to be cleverer than them.â€He gives me two freshly caught mud crabs, which, when&nbspboiled,&nbspproduce the freshest meat broken off the shell. Simplicity and patience are key here. Life is slow and meandering. Villagers paddle along in their canoes to the sound of birds and the rik rik of crickets. You quickly&nbsplearn thereâ€™s no need to chase time.Corey takes me to Karawara. At every turn, the islanders greet me&nbspwarmly. A man stops on the path and pulls out some betel nuts and lime powder from his bag, which I chew, turning my lips red. Iâ€™m invited to eat taro&nbspand freshly cooked fish stew and drink&nbsphomebrew. The village is just 30 minutes walk from one end to the other but is so overflowing with life, generosity and community that I wonder how or why this place is slowly slipping away to western mores.Itâ€™s clear the spirit of Engelhardt endures. One of the men shows me old photos of him â€“ whom they call Tokelau or Mr Coconut â€“ sitting on a chair looking into the camera with a haunted expression on his face. Apparently&nbsphe was a good man but the customs â€“ nudism and all â€“ disconcerted them. Some called him a ghost.Papua New Guinea hit with 6.4-magnitude earthquakeThe local legends and myths border on the fantastically insane but somehow seem believable here. Corey speaks of the magic men who went through extreme initiations, fasting for months, eating 20 or more ginger roots in a go, and other crazy acts of torture before they acquired magic powers. These men could become tiny and transport themselves to different places by stepping on rocks or were carried around by flying foxes. They had power over nature â€“ asking the coconut tree to bend down and provide them with coconuts.There are darker things too. Cannibalism. Coreyâ€™s grandmother, who died aged 115 last year, tasted human flesh. She told of how the tribe caught a man, tied him up, removed his eyes and turned his head around, then kept him by the fire still alive for three days while they collected sweet potatoes until finally throwing him in â€“ a custom which has fortunately also slipped away.At some point, I express an interest in fishing and lo and behold the next morning four boys rock up in their boat with spearguns and goggles and take me with them to the other side of the island to catch fish. The boat stops and sways as waves dash&nbspagainst the rocky face. Iâ€™m feeling a&nbsplittle grim but try not to show it. Wilson hands me my fishing tool â€“ a homemade speargun thatâ€™s been whittled out of wood with a thick rubber band attached to it. Iâ€™m supposed to get in the water and load this with a spear before catching something.â€œDonâ€™t point it at anyone, it goes off easy,â€ he warns.Iâ€™m not convinced by their chances, but the boys are specialists, ing with ease like they have since they were kids. Iâ€™m less effective but itâ€™s exhilarating all the same. The coral is teeming with marine life yet to be diminished by overfishing. We return with a bucket of multicoloured tropical fish that we&nbspsmoke&nbspover the fire and share. I doubt Iâ€™ve had fresher â€“ straight from sea to coals to stomach.On my last evening, I sit on the sand&nbspand watch villagers paddling back to their island, canoes loaded with crops. Songs echo out into the air as the light fades and the mountains in the distance get dimmer and dimmer and thenâ€¦&nbspsilence. Just the waves and the darkness and the stars, hundreds and thousands of them, glimmering in the sky.It is a place of perfect peace.The mornings have been a little overcast so far but the final day brings a cloudless blue sky. The sun is peeping over the distant mountains of New Ireland. I rush to the water and see it rising, shyly at first, then exploding into golden beams that illuminate the world. Augustus would have been happy. But there is a final twist to the tale.While we are waiting for the boat to take us back to the mainland, one of the villagers â€“ Vapot, a quiet one who speaks little English â€“ tells Corey that two Germans came in 2002 and she and some of the other villagers went with them and dug up bones in the north of the island.It was the same spot where Augustus planted his flowers. Iâ€™m frankly agog. But then again thereâ€™s nothing too fanciful about this strange, crazy, beautiful place that should surprise me. He was right here all along.The trip was organised through the PNG Tourism Authority. Air Niugini flies daily from Singapore&nbspto Port Moresby and has connecting flights to Rabaul. That is more than double the 18.9 per cent currently charged on overdrafts with its standard current account and in line with some of the most expensive credit cards available.Nationwide will also no longer allow customers with its FlexPlus account a Â£250 overdraft without charges.The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has banned daily fees on overdrafts, requiring lenders to charge through an annual interest rate instead by April 2020, following years of complaints by consumer groups that customers were being charged excessive fees.Although an interest rate is clearer than the confusing And it gives a hint at what that future could look like: 5G iPhones that use Appleâ€™s own chips.Apple has&nbsplong been rumoured to be working on its first 5G iPhone for 2020, putting it behind competitors including&nbspSamsung. Apple's model&nbspis still expected to arrive next year, but the first of them will likely rely on modem chips made by Qualcomm.But, after that, Apple is expected to use the people and patents it acquired through the Intel acquisition to create new kinds of modems for its own iPhones, in line with what has become a central commitment for the company.Under the deal, about 2,200 Intel employees will join Apple, along with intellectual property, equipment and leases.&nbspApple will then&nbsphave 17,000 wireless technology patents, ranging from cellular communication standards to modems, making it a more powerful player in the global licensing talks that will likely be held by major 5G patent holders such as Huawei Technologies.Created with Sketch.Gadgets and tech news in pictures Show all 25Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Chief engineer of LIFT aircraft Balazs Kerulo demonstrates the company's Hexa personal drone craft in Lago Vista, Texas on June 3 2019225 Project Scarlett to succeed Xbox OneMicrosoft announced Project Scarlett, the successor to the Xbox One, at E3 2019. This is a production preview of the Jaguar I-PACE, which will be revealed next year and on the road in 2018After the deal, Intel will retain the right to develop modems for non-smartphone applications, such as PCs, industrial equipment and self-driving cars.New iPhone line-up said to be revealed in huge new leakModem chips connect devices like the iPhone to wireless data networks, but Apple has always relied on outside suppliers for the part. Intel has positioned itself as the sole source of iPhone modem chips over the past year after Apple got into a prolonged legal fight with previous supplier Qualcomm over patent licensing practices.Apple, based in&nbspCupertino, California,&nbspreached a surprise settlement in April that called for the iPhone to once again use Qualcomm modem chips. Within hours, Intel said it would quit the smartphone modem business.Appleâ€™s acquisitions have mostly been much smaller companies, making the Intel deal its second-largest ever after its $3.2bn purchase of Beats Electronics in 2014.The deal with Intel will bolster Appleâ€™s goal to make its own modem chip. Two of Appleâ€™s biggest global rivals â€“ Samsung Electronics and Huawei â€“ already have the ability to self-supply modem chips.Technology news publication The Information last year reported Appleâ€™s efforts to develop its own modem, but the iPhone maker&nbspnever formally acknowledged it. In February, Reuters reported that Apple moved its modem engineering efforts into the same chip design unit that makes the custom processors for its devices, signalling a doubling down on the pursuit of self-designed modem chip.Apple chief executive Tim Cook has also long said the company wants to control its own technological fate â€“ analysts call this&nbspthe â€œCook Doctrineâ€.â€œWe believe that we need to own and control the primary technologies behind the products that we make,â€ Tim Cook told investors back in 2009.The purchase of Intelâ€™s assets could help Apple meet its aggressive timeline for producing a modem.A person familiar with the matter said Apple plans to use Qualcommâ€™s modem technology for a 5G iPhone in 2020 but wants to have its own ready for use&nbspby 2021.But any replacement of Qualcomm is likely to happen in phases, this person said, as Apple builds up its ability to ensure that its modems work on all the networks and countries where it sells phones. Ensuring worldwide compatibility is Qualcommâ€™s historical strength, and Apple might still have to rely on the firm&nbspfor some modems during a transition period to its own devices.â€œThereâ€™s a fierce desire (at Apple) to have independence, but they also realise it has to be done responsibly,â€ this person said.Appleâ€™s licence deal with Qualcomm lasts six years and its accompanying chip supply agreement could also last that long, said one chip industry veteran who requested anonymity to discuss confidential matters. Apple is likely to continue to use the San Diego firmâ€™s chips in its flagship models even if it phases in its own silicon for lower-end and older models, this person said.Apple has engaged with Taiwanâ€™s Global Unichip Corp, a chip design house in which Apple supplier Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co is an investor, to explore a modem design, but the work is in early stages.â€œClearly Apple saw the handwriting on the wall, because they came around and did a deal with Qualcomm,â€ this person said.Apple declined to comment on its plans, and Qualcomm and Global Unichip did not immediately respond to a request for comment.The most valuable aspect of the Intel deal for Apple could turn out to be patents. To sell a 5G iPhone, Apple will need to strike deals with the major holders of 5G patents, including Nokia, Ericsson, Huawei and Qualcomm. Apple executed a licensing deal with Qualcomm, but it has not disclosed whether it has deals in place with the others.Erick Robinson, a patent attorney who had worked in Qualcommâ€™s licensing ision in Asia, said the patents could give Apple better leverage in licensing talks.â€œI donâ€™t think Intel has quite the portfolio that Qualcomm has, but they certainly have a large enough one to impact the valuations when it comes to a cross-licensing deal,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™ll save (Apple) a huge chunk of change in cross-licence deals.â€Additional reporting by agenciesBe inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsBe inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsRocket was supposed to hop off the ground â€“ but stayed put, and became engulfed by fireClick to followThe Independent TechSpaceX's Starhopper â€“ a prototype of the rocket it hopes will one day fly around the solar system â€“ had a failed launch test that ended with it being surrounded by flames.The company was aiming to try the first untethered test of the rocket, which was intended to allow it to jump up into the air and then come back down again, without the restraining ties that have held it down in previous attempts.But as the test began, the rocket failed to launch and it stayed on the ground as flames poured out of its rocket. Another flame flew out of the top of the rocket, as can be seen on the video.The rocket itself appeared to survive without problems, but it is just the latest in a run of issues. Thatâ€™s what the people at the Stonewall Inn did that fateful night in 1969. They resisted arrest and the status quo because they knew that their right to love and exist was equal to their heterosexual and cisgender counterparts.â€™â€˜Growing up I just did not see myself reflected within the history books. Stonewall was about the freedom to love without fear.â€™850 Ruth Hunt, CEO of Stonewallâ€˜We named ourselves after this historic moment and we continue to honour those involved by naming the meeting rooms in our London office after some of the leaders, including a lesbian woman of colour called Storme DeLarverie and two trans women of colour, Sylvia Rivera and Marsha P Johnson.â€™950 Rikki Beadle-Blair, creator and performerâ€˜I put my heart and soul into the script for Stonewall. provide adequate proof of their sexuality.The proportion of asylum claims from members of the LGBT+ community that have been rejected by the Home Office has surged in recent years, government data released last year showed.In total, 78 per cent of asylum claims that included a reference to sexual orientation were refused last year 1,464 people â€“ up from 964 rejected claims in 2015.This is what LGBTQI+ people go through to gain asylum in the UKDr Tschalaerâ€™s study found people who were more open about their sexuality and gender identity in their country of origin as well as the country of arrival were much more likely to be granted asylum, in part because they were more likely to receive support for the preparation of their asylum interview.Her research suggested&nbspthose who felt unable to be open about their sexuality prior to leaving their home country were at a disadvantage when applying for asylum.LGBTQI+ asylum seekers who felt forced to hide their sexuality andor gender identity, and who felt uncomfortable talking about it were usually rejected, as were those who were married or had children in their countries of origin,â€ she said.â€œThis was either countryâ€™Click to followThe IndependentThe president of Tanzania has inaugurated a huge controversial hydroelectric dam project in a wildlife reserve at the centre of warnings over rhino and elephant populations.Conservation groups have opposed the Stieglerâ€™s Gorge project in the Selous Game Reserve, the countryâ€™s largest wildlife area, which Unesco says has one of the most significant concentrations of elephants and black rhinos.President John Magufuli called the project â€œthe start of economic liberationâ€, saying the reserve â€“ which is also a haven for cheetahs and giraffes â€“ has been considered a potential energy source for decades.Only one in 10 households in in the East African nation has access to the national grid and electricity prices are high.â€œBeginning today, this will indicate that Tanzania is an independent country... and not a poor country,â€ Mr Magufuli said.Created with Sketch.Conservation success for the Gorongosa National Park in Mozambique River, in a Unesco World Heritage Site that is one of Africaâ€™s largest protected areas and relatively undisturbed by humans.The president said he hoped the project would boost industrial development.Hunting group â€˜undermining protections for endangered animalsâ€™â€œItâ€™s time to benefit from our national resources,â€ he said.Opponents of the project say it could also threaten the livelihoods of tens of thousands of people downstream, who depend on the river for agriculture and fisheries.Last month the IUCN, together with Unescoâ€™s World Heritage Centre, called for an immediate halt to logging and other preparations, warning of â€œirreversible damageâ€ if it went ahead.&nbspAn independent review commissioned by IUCN highlighted the â€œinadequacyâ€ of the environmental impact assessment.â€œIt would cut the heart out of the Selous reserve, with catastrophic impacts on the siteâ€™s wildlife and habitats,â€ said Peter Shadie, of the IUCNâ€™s World small part of the reserve â€“ just 3 per cent of the total area.â€The president said the dam would not only meet national electricity needs but would also provide power to export.Tanzanian president Protection Initiative said the fact that a leading wildlife country was â€œprepared to contemplate drowning their natural crown jewels in pursuit of megawatts must serve as a serious wake-up call to everyone in conservationâ€.â€œWe need to make the case urgently that wildlife conservation can not only pay for itself, but that it is often the best way for the human populations who live around it title: deal boris follow may brexit door
story: He is only Prime Minister because of Theresa Mayâ€™s failure to get Britain out of the EU on March .If Boris canâ€™t get Brexit done, then heâ€™ll be done.So whatâ€™s the plan  Well, it is to seek a deal while preparing for No Deal.Boris has long regarded a genuine threat to walk away without a deal as being a bit like the Trident nuclear deterrent: Because you have it, you donâ€™t have to use it.But as one of those involved in devising this approach tells me, for it to work, â€œboth elements of the strategy have to be credibleâ€. In other words, both the No Deal preparation and the proposed deal must be realistic.This is where his key Brexit lieutenants Dominic Cummings and David Frost come in.They might be backroom appointments but they are as â€”not more â€” important to the success of Borisâ€™s premiership as the Cabinet appointments he has made.Cummings is a unique figure in Westminster. He is interested in getting things done with little regard to what people think of him and the political niceties.It is thanks to Benedict Cumberbatch that Cummings has attracted something close to celebrity status in political circles. Cumberbatch played Cummings in the TV drama Brexit: The Uncivil War.He captured brilliantly Cummingsâ€™ drive and determination to win as the campaign chief for Vote Leave, and the fact he doesnâ€™t care whose ego he ruffles in the process.In his new job, Cummingsâ€™ determination is already clear.Yesterday he was meant to be on the operating table under general anaesthetic.But once the offer came from Boris, he cancelled the operation. I am told he wonâ€™t have it done now until after October , Borisâ€™s deadline for getting Brexit done.Cummings came in because the chance of getting the Vote Leave team back together to deliver Brexit after three years of drt simply had to be taken. The big challenge for this team is to get the UK ready for a No Deal Brexit.Cummings is well suited to his task. He knows how Whitehall works and how to succeed despite intense opposition he drove through Michael Goveâ€™s Free Schools, which have proved hugely successful, against the objections of the educational establishment.Strikingly, in Borisâ€™s new Government it is now Gove who is in charge of the No Deal planning.Getting the logistics and the necessary contingency plans sorted is one aspect of No Deal planning, and one that was shamefully neglected under Mrs May. But there also needs to be a political strategy for it.Many in the EU are convinced â€” thanks to the antics of Dominic Grieve, Philip Hammond and co â€” that Parliament will block No Deal.Or thatthe UK did leave without a deal on Halloween, it would come crawling back by Christmas.So they reckon there is no need to compromise as No Deal either wonâ€™t happen or will be only a temporary affair.The best way to deal with both the Parliamentary opposition to No Deal and the belief that the UK would come crawling back is for Boris to take a lead in the polls.If it was clear that a general election would lead to a majority for Boris, then Parliament would be less likely to throw obstacles in his way.Thatâ€™s why Boris, in his Downing Street speech, tried to address the issues that cost the Tories their majority in : Social care, schools funding and police cuts.If the EU thought that Boris could do No Deal, and could politically sustain it, then it would have to decide whether it was prepared to compromise to avoid No Deal.The Irish Taoiseach, Leo Varadkar, would have to decide whether it is worth sticking with a backstop that is going to cause the very thing it was meant to avoid, a hard border on the island of Ireland.Varadkar would also have to consider whether he really wants to go through with No Deal when it would do more damage to the Irish economy than the UKâ€™s. This is where David Frost comes in.No, not the late, great TV personality but the former Foreign Office diplomat who is going to be Borisâ€™s point man for negotiations with the EU.Frost knows his way round the chancelleries of Europe, he is a former Foreign Office Europe Director and he also knows what Boris wants on Brexit.He was his special adviser when Boris was Foreign Secretary and was there when Boris decided to quit over Mrs Mayâ€™s Chequers plan.His role is to craft a Brexit agreement that delivers what Boris thinks the UK needs AND one that has a chance of being accepted by the EUthe alternative is No Deal. This isnâ€™t going to be easy, and it isnâ€™t going to be done quickly.Those involved admit thatthe EU is going to blink, it will not be until the October EU Council at the earliest, which is just two weeks away from the October  deadline. As one of those working in the new No puts it: â€œFasten your seatbelts, itâ€™s going to be a bumpy ride.â€But after years in which the EU thought they had the measure of the British Prime Minister, we now have a team who might just have what it takes to pull Brexit back from the brink.Â Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: A long-abandoned arcade in Dundee city centre is set to be reborn as a series of retail units, pending approval by city planners.Hynds Amusement Arcade was snapped up by local property firm West One Property in January for a reported Â£,.West One has now submitted its redevelopment plan to Dundee City Council for review, with a decision expected in September.Lee Chadwick, director of the firm, wants to ide the large space into three retail units to attract new tenants.He said: â€œWe hope to seek approval to split the building into three normal-sized units.â€œThe unit currently is too large â€“ it is laid out to maximise floorspace which is useful for an arcade.â€œBy splitting the units it opens up the property to multiple uses. This will benefit Reform Street and the city centre.â€The application by West One, based in the cityâ€™s Blinshall Street, is the first by any party to bring the amusement arcade back into use.But the plan comes hot on the heels of a blip in confidence among business owners on Reform Street, who spoken of its â€œsecond album syndromeâ€ following a resurgence in food outlets that began with Project Pizza in .The eatery, initially hailed as the shape of things to come, closed without warning last month and the unit is now advertised for let.Proprietors such as Akky Hayat â€“ who runs German Doner Kebab and Fatburger â€“ say punitive business rates are discouraging others from opening shops on the street.Mr Chadwick has not been discouraged. He added: â€œFootfall is rising and there are positive steps in the regeneration of the area.â€œThe demise of Project Pizza is a minor setback to a street that is on the up.â€However, it is hard to ignore the units once home to Victoria Wine, TSB and Swinton Insurance, which have remained conspicuously empty long after they have closed.

title: a look back at some of dundee uniteds most famous foes including messi and gazza
story: Dundee Unitedâ€™s final friendly of the summer comes on Saturday when preparations for the build-up to the Championship season are completed with a -mile trip south to face Shrewsbury Town.The game will be a valuable exercise for boss Robbie Neilson as he makes sure his players have had enough game time to be ready for the opener against Inverness on Saturday week.In terms of prestige, thereâ€™s no denying the English League One opposition fall into the â€œmodestâ€ category.There was a time, though, when the Tangerines were in the habit of hosting top opposition at this time of year.It led to some great occasions â€“ and great victories â€“ at Tannadice. Today the Tele looks back at some of those memorable days.DUNDEE UTD  SPURS Tuesday, August , Att: ,A Spurs side that boasted the likes of Argentine World Cup winners Ossie Ardiles and Ricky Villa, Englandâ€™s Glenn Hoddle and the new strike partnership of Steve Archibald and Garth Crooks, were blown away by a United side that would reach the peak of its powers over the next few seasons.The Londoners started well and led through a Crooks goal as early as the th minute but, by the break, Billy Kirwood had levelled.After the interval, Jim McLeanâ€™s men stepped up a gear and goals from Graeme Payne, Derek Addison and Paul Sturrock gave them a handsome victory over a team that, within a year, would win a classic FA Cup Final against Manchester City.DUNDEE UTD  ASTON VILLA Sunday, August , Att: ,A year before that superb display against Spurs, United entertained Aston Villa, with striker Paul Sturrock once again to the fore.With United dominating from start to finish, â€œLuggyâ€ bagged a hat-trick to send Ron Saundersâ€™ outfit heading back south with their tails between their legs.If not too much was made about the victory, it was a sign the Tangerines were on the verge of big things and, within months, McLeanâ€™s team would secure the clubâ€™s first major honour in the shape of the League Cup.Itâ€™s also worth remembering, in just two years, Villa would be champions of England and, a year later, more than half the team that ran out at Tannadice would start their winning European Cup Final against Bayern Munich.DUNDEE UTD  EVERTON Tuesday, July , Att: ,.This game was a testimonial for long-serving Maurice Malpas, with his influential former coach Walter Smith bringing Everton to mark the occasion.If the English Premier League giants were already a sizeable draw, their signing of Paul Gascoigne, who would make his debut, brought extra attention that saw news as well as football media heading for Tannadice, although tragic events in Paris as a Concorde crashed, meant, ultimately, actual coverage of it was limited.As was often the case with Gazza, trouble was not far away. He had a first-half flare-up with Joachim Fernandez that saw the home trialist take such exception that boss Paul Sturrock took him off before he was sent off.Malpasâ€™ big night was marked with a win, David Weir giving the visitors the lead before two goals in three second-half minutes from Steven Thompson and Alex Mathie turned things round.DUNDEE UNITED  BARCELONA Saturday, July , Att: ,For the second year running, the Catalan giants had used Unitedâ€™s St Andrews University training base for the first week of their pre-season build-up and that meant fans were treated to a second summer friendly in a row against them at Tannadice.A year earlier, minus Lionel Messi because he was still on holiday, Ronaldinho and Thierry Henry were the stars as a last-gasp goal by the French great gave them victory.With Messi starting, the  friendly saw the Spaniards really turn up as they blasted five past the Tangerines .For once, though, such a reversal was surely acceptable, such was the quality of the opposition and just the sight of one of the worldâ€™s greatest players in action meant everyone went home happy. title: letters week 24
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site isÂ  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,Further to your article #Three amigos clean up in Lochgilphead#, Friday May , I would like to add the lane behind Lochgilphead Bowling Club is often filled with fresh poo.I#m sick of coming over nearly every day and finding poo all over the lane. The lane floods, so between trying to dodge puddles, you land in dog dirt.I wish they would fix the path because a lot of people use it, some of them pensioners with or parents with prams.Celia MacFarlane, Lochgilphead.Sir,Seven out of ten people with diabetes feel overwhelmed by the demands of their condition and this signicantly affects their mental and physical health.That is why we are calling for new national standards for diabetes emotional and mental health support and to increase support available in Argyll to people living with diabetes.As part of Diabetes UKâ€™s Diabetes Weekwe are urging people in Argyll to #SeeDiabetesDferently and back our campaign for national standards for diabetes mental health support and services.Our recently published research revealed the relentless nature of diabetes can impact peopleâ€™s emotional well-being and mental health, ranging from day-to-day frustration and low mood, to specic psychological and mental health dficulties including clinical depression and anxiety.The findings, published in the report #Too often missing: Making emotional and psychological support routine in diabetes care#, show that diabetes is much more than a physical condition â€“ and that emotional and psychological demands of living with diabetes should be recognised and support provided.Diabetes Scotland is urgently calling on the NHS to create national standards for diabetes emotional and mental health services. These should ensure everyone receives #joined up# care, that they are asked how they are feeling as part of every diabetes appointment and that a mental health professional with knowledge of diabetes is part of every diabetes care team.To sign our petition, go to diabetes.org.uk missingAngela Mitchell, National Director of Diabetes Scotland.Sir,I#m asking residents in the Highlands and Islands to give their views on Conservative proposals for tackling serious crime.In order to provide Scotland with an alternative to Nicola Sturgeon and the SNP in , we are keen to gain feedback from as many people to our policy proposals to make them as relevant as possible to the needs and aspirations of everyone in Scotland.Too many people in Scotland are affected by the behaviour of serious criminals. This needs to be properly addressed and my colleague Liam Kerr MSP, shadow Justice Secretary, has outlined key policy proposals in a member#s bill in the Scottish Parliament to tackle this scourge.It would give Scottish judges the power to impose whole le sentences to those convicted of the most serious violent and sexual crimes including the murder of a police officer.The courts would still have discretion to impose the appropriate sentence based on all the facts of each case, as they do in England and Wales where such a provision already exists.The proposed Whole Le CustodyBill will not mean the perpetrators of a particular crime will always receive a whole le sentence, but rather that the courts will have the power to impose one where there is sufficient justication.We have started the consultation and experts and members of the public are invited to register their views.Email me at donald.cameron.msp@parliament.scot or write to me at Donald Cameron MSP,  George Street, Oban, PA NT, with your views.MSP Donald Cameron, Highlands and Islands.Sir,The SNP has warned Scotlandâ€™s NHS is under threat from a Tory-Trump trade deal that could leave the Scottish Government without a veto over a post-Brexit deal that sells Scotland out.This stark warning follows the revelations from Donald Trump that in terms of trade deals, everything, including the NHS, would be on the table.At Prime Ministers Questions, SNP Deputy Westminster Leader Kirsty Blackman MP said Donald Trump and the Tories could not be trusted on the NHS and criticised the UK government for plotting to take powers away from the Scottish Parliament that would allow it to safeguard Scotlandâ€™s NHS.The threats to Scotland#s NHS are growing under the prospect of a hard-right Tory-Trump Brexit trade deal. Those threats could undermine the integrity and independence of our Scottish NHS.The UK Tories will block any potential veto by the Scottish Government over such a damaging deal.The SNP government will fight to the end to defend Scotland#s public services from this unprecedented Tory Brexit danger. Our NHS must remain in public hands. It is not, and should never be, up for sale.Scotland has been completely ignored throughout the Brexit process and Tory plans to grab powers from the Scottish Parliament will leave us even more exposed.It is clearer than ever that the only way to properly protect Scotland#s interests, and keep our NHS in public hands, is with the full powers of independence.MP Brendan O#Hara, Argyll and Bute.

story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site isÂ  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThere was a palpable air of excitement in the air as racing ed to Kilmartin.The course, in the shadow of Carnasserie Castle and newly reclaimed from a dense layer of bracken, lived up to its reputation as a true championship test.The course # home to the only ever Scottish round of the GP World Motocross Championship in June  # played host to round five of the  Scottish Twin Shock championship in the first race to have been held there in decades.The track itself isÂ  natural undulating land and not a man-made track, described by racing aficionados as a place for #vintage scrambling motocross#.Hot and dry weather in the week leading up to the event on Saturday June  was interrupted by a shower on race morning and this, combined with cut vegetation on the track, made for interesting conditions early in proceedings # which simply added to the excitement.Ricky Caldwell, chairman of the Scottish Twin Shock Scramble Club, said: #The sighting laps caused a little bit of a hold at the bottom of the hills due to the rain which had fallen which made a couple of the hills very slippery at the start of the day.#A few riders had not realised this and had a little sit down on them to gather their thoughts and then have another go. title: kilmartin twinshocks race report
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site isÂ  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe Nowby Jim GrieveRace day on the iconic former Grand Prix track at Carnasserie Castle on June  started off on a sombre note, as riders all paid respects with a minute of silence for fallen riding legendary Ian â€˜Lugsâ€™ Robertson.Many riders sported Ianâ€™s riding number  on their bikes.The racing started with group one and the flying EVO cc class with Peter O#Neil, and William Penrice showing the bigger bikes how it should be done. Peter O#Neil edged out Penrice in race one, but Penrice would take his revenge in race two and it was all to play for in the final encounter. Peter O#Neil was up to the task and would take the overall, with Penrice a deserved second andÂ  Damian Carter would third.The four stroke class was enthralling, with Sam Sibbald thundering around the Kilmartin track, big Andy Malloch and his Armstrong chasing him all the way to the flag and winning the final race but not the overall. Sam would be the victor followed by Andy and a consistent Keith Stanford third.For the youth class it was a day of mixed fortunes and consistency would be the key, with Jordan Graham coming out on top ahead of James Forrest and picking up a superb third overall was Rhys Brown.Pre- action would see committee man and track builder Grant McClure and his Maico, with three decades of riding under his belt, become the overall winner ahead of Callum Wilson on the superbly prepared Honda.The Twinshock under cc event would be a three race win for the flying Calum Kilgour and his cc Yamaha ahead of Jim Grieve, who would have some bike issues but would bring home his Honda in second fighting off a very persistent David Lawson and Gordon Peterson but it would be Gordon that would hold the third place trophy with some consistent riding.The Twinshock open class event would be a spectacular sight as cc Hondas and Maicos battled their way around the bracken.In race one there was a very small gap between first and second place and a similarly small gap between third. Brian Alexander would take the win from Craig â€˜Smitchâ€™ Smith, and John Crawford would come home in third with a notable mention to the very unlucky Paul Chiappa who had his fair share of misfortunes throughout the day, as his seat was torn from his bike at the top of one of the steep climbs. The overall would end up the same as the first race with Brian, taking the win from Craig Smith and John Crawford bringing the big Honda home in third.In the over s class it was a triumphant day for John Lamont with three resounding victories. Balter are a contemporary folk quartet who have emerged from the music scene in Newcastle but are strongly influenced by their shared love of Scottish music.These four multi-talented womenfollow up their success at Glasgowâ€™s Celtic Connections festival and as finalists in the Battle of the Folk Bands in Edinburgh to bring their exuberance and infectious live energy back to Tayvallich after a barnstorming gig there a year ago.Playing music from Shetland, the Borders, the Western Isles and Ireland, from foot-stomping jigs and reels to soulful Gaelic melodies, the foursome combine traditional and original material. The interplay between fiddles, mandolin and accordion creates a distinctive sound of intricate arrangements that mixes Balterâ€™s traditional heritage with contemporary influences.The celebrations continue when the Tayvallich Big Weekend gets under way on Friday July  with a barbeque and live music at the Tayvallich Inn. The focus moves to the village hall on Saturday July .Starting at am, there are games sports stalls from local businesses, voluntary groups and organizations and fabulous food and drink. Pooches both pedigree and potpourri have their day at the ever-popular Dog Show.The Family Ceilidh on Saturday evening has live music from the exhilarating Argyll Ceilidh Trail band. The weekend is rounded off on Sunday morning with the World Crab Fishing Championship on the Tayvallich village pontoon.The party continues on Wednesday July , when gypsy jazz quartet Latchepen roll up. Latchepen are a London-based gypsy jazz outfit comprising four musicians from dferent corners of the globe, brought together by a shared admiration of Django Reinhardt and all that swings. Acoustic by nature but with projection and a heartbeat that rival any amp or drum, this is jazz on a string with influences ranging from Romani music to bebob.Fun, games, music, food and drink # Tayvallich is the place to be this month.Balter will rock Tayvallich on Thursday July  at pm before Latchepen gets everyone dancing on Wednesday July  at pm. title: happy-camper-braden-pitches-number-10
story: CAMPING out for an entire year has earned a Borders boy a trip to Downing Street.Braden Collins spent  months sleeping under canvas in the garden of his Yarrow Valley home to raise money for Diabetes UK.And even when his family went on holiday, the then primary school pupil took his tent and sleeping bag.The -year-old has now been honoured with the Young Persons Outstanding Award by the charity.And he also accepted an invitation to meet Prime Minister Theresa May at number .Braden, who lives near St Marys Loch, told the Border : ldquoI feel like itrsquos a big achievement to win the Young Personrsquos Outstanding Contribution Inspire Award from Diabetes Scotland and Irsquom really happy about it.ldquoMy dad has Type  diabetes so I wanted to raise money to help find a cure."Sleeping outside in a tent for a year was something I wanted to do ndash it was a bit hard sometimes when it was raining or snowing but mostly it was fun."When we went on holiday we had to take my tent and fit it in the car along with my sleeping bag and blow up bed.ldquoGetting to go to  Downing Street was also really special."I was very surprised to get the invitation but it was great to represent Diabetes UK volunteers at such an important event."Following an initial fundraising target of pound, Braden raised over pound for Diabetes UK.He has also spoken about diabetes and how it affects his dad and his family.Braden featured in several Borderarticles during his year-long fundraiser.And he also appeared on ITVrsquos Good Morning Britain.Braden added: ldquoI see my dad living with diabetes and know it can be dficult at times."I wish everyone knew how it can affect people and that you are constantly having to test your blood sugar levels.Diabetes is a condition where there is too much glucose in the blood because the body cannot use it properly.If not managed well, both Type  and Type  diabetes can lead to devastating complications.With the right treatment, knowledge and support people living with diabetes can lead a long, full and healthy le.Braden was one of a group of Diabetes UK volunteers invited to meet the Prime Minister at the Downing Street reception.Angela Mitchell, national director of Diabetes Scotland, said: ldquoBraden is an exceptional young volunteer and wersquore so pleased that he has chosen to support the charity."He has shown tremendous commitment and innovation with his unusual fundraising challenge and we really appreciate his efforts.ldquoOur volunteers are out there working hard in the community day in and day out."Our much-needed work wouldnrsquot be possible without their incredible support and I would like to extend my sincere thanks to all of our volunteers who make an enormous dference through their support.The Inspire Awards celebrate Diabetes Scotlandrsquos dedicated volunteers who campaign to improve the quality of care available to people with diabetes, fundraise for pioneering research and raise awareness to stem the rising tide of diabetes.
