title: metal-detecting-fan-hailed-hero-finding-wedding-ring-fell-sea
story: Toby Binnian, from Newbyth ndash between Tyninghame and Whitekirk ndash and Holly Clement got married on Saturday.But the ringplunged into the waters off Tyninghame during a swim the very next day.Devastated, Holly sent a social media SOS to Dean Houston after she discovered the existence of East Lothian Metal Detecting Club.And when Dean kindly agreed to sweep the wet sand at Tyninghame on Monday morning with his metal detector when the tide was out, he surprised even himself when he found what he described as a ldquoneedle in a haystack.Holly, who grew up in Haddington, said it had been an eventful start to married le but they were delighted to once again be in possession of the cherished band.She said: ldquoToby was so upset that he lost it and it is more relief for him than anything ."Friends and family were devastated for him and we are just so happy to get the ring back.PE teacher Toby, , and dentist Holly, , first met while at school at Edinburgh Academy and have been together for  years.They were married at the Log Cabin at Ravensheugh on Saturday and decided to mark their first full day as husband and we with a swim at nearby Tyninghame.Holly recalled: ldquoAll our friends arrived and we were on the beach going to go for a swim."We debated about whether to keep the ring on or off and we thought because it was quite a snug fit that it would be fine.ldquoToby went out for a swim while we were jumping through the waves.ldquoI donrsquot know what possessed him but someone asked himthe ring was OK and he tested it to see whether it would go over his knuckle.ldquoThen, all of a sudden, it went plop into the water and he was panicking.ldquoIt is a palladium ring and not a very bright white colour, so it disappeared into the murky waters and we were chest high in the water.Amongst the panic, the couple, who now live in York, decided to bring in outside help.A search of Facebook brought up the newly-formed East Lothian Metal Detecting Club.Holly said: ldquoWe just said: lsquoPlease help, my idiot new husband has dropped his ring in the sea.rsquoShe remained ldquoblindly optimistic of being reunited with the ring because they had a rough idea where it had fallen into the water.Within an hour, the group got in touch and, after a check of tide times, arrived at the beach on Monday morning.Holly said: ldquoI had slightly given up hope and walked up to sit with family on the headland and stay out of the way.ldquoI just heard lots of cheering and we all sprinted down to check it was real.Dean, from the local metal detecting club, was delighted to be able to help and within an hour had tracked down the ring in the wet sand.The Dunbar resident thought it would be like finding ldquoa needle in a haystack and added: ldquoI was expecting an area of a couple of feet by a couple of feet but it was more like  or  feet square that they gave me.Dean was given a helping hand by his black Labrador Roxy.He said: ldquoMy dog was digging holes and I just walked over and the metal detector beeped.ldquoThey all started running up and giving me hugs, which is a bit embarrassing when you donrsquot know them!ldquoThen they were all trying to phone Toby.Holly said she was forever thankful to Dean, adding: ldquoHe was just so lovely, unassuming and he was just great.ldquoToby is a little bit scared and does not know whether to keep the ring on or take it off!ldquoHe is wearing it just now but he is thinking about getting it resized.Anyone interested in finding out more about the metal detecting club should email elmdclub@yahoo or search for East Lothian Metal Detecting Club on Facebook.

title: teenager-spat-bus-driver-argument-ticket
story: Nathan Cook spat on bus employee Colin Dickson during an altercation while the vehicle was on the townrsquos High Street last year.Cook, , had attempted to buy a ticket which was not for sale at that time and proceeded to get into a row with the driver.During the argument, Cook got close to the partition glass that separates the driver from the public and spat at him.Cook appeared at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Wednesday where he pleaded guilty to the assault on Mr Dickson.Prosecutor Clare Kennedy said that Mr Dickson was driving the public bus on Tranent High Street at about .pm on April  last year.Ms Kennedy said: ldquoMr Cook got on the bus and asked for a ticket which could not be produced at that time of day.ldquoThe driver told Mr Cook of this and an argument between them [broke out] and came to an end and Mr Cook sat down and Mr Dickson carried on the bus route.ldquoBut they began arguing again as the bus pulled up to a stop on Tranent High Street. Mr Cook put his face up to the glass and spat through the glass and [the spit] landed on [the driverrsquos] arm.Sherf Pamela Bowman told Cook: ldquoThis was a bad, bad thing to do. The bus driver was only doing his job.Sherf Bowman deferred sentence to July next year for Cook, from Edinburgh, to be of good behaviour.Cook admitted assaulting Colin Dickson by spitting on his body on April  last year.

title: tim-39-s-tales-happy-ending-last-mistreated-women
story: AGNES Blakelived in Haddington in the early s. She was regarded as an lsquoincomerrsquo, however, as she was born at Bolton, a couple of miles away, where she likely spent much of her childhood. When and how she came to Haddington I cannot say, or what her childhood was like, but it seems clear she was poor and for her, le was a struggle.She seems to have found companionship with Elizabeth Golight, who was Haddington born and bred. Perhaps they were neighbours in Haddington. Whatever their circumstances, they drew the attention of others and found themselves in court.This is how they came to the attention of another woman from another century: Ros Parkyn. She sadly died only a few weeks ago, but her le was full of stories and love for people, and she had an especially sharp eye for injustice and empathy for people unfairly treated or judged.Ros was browsing in the John Gray Centre in  and noticed a temporary display of mixed objects and records from their collections. There was a volume of court records laid open for perusal and Ros peered at the entries.The entries hadnrsquot been transcribed but she could just make out that they were accounts of the trials of two women who lived in Haddington in . The th-century handwriting, with its dferent spelling, was very dficult to read in the display case, and so Ros asked the staffit was possible to take the document from the case.A friendly and helpful staff member obliged, then sat down with Ros and assisted her to transcribe the writing. It wasnrsquot easy sometimes they couldnrsquot decipher a word at all, while others seemed to be spelt dferently at dferent times. But gradually, as Ros wrote the words down, she became introduced to Agnes and Elizabeth.There were accounts of others too, but she was particularly taken with the account of these two women, the language used to describe them, and the cruel punishments they suffered.In the account, Agnesrsquos name is spelt in three dferent ways, but was likely Blake or Black.Here is the transcription Ros made:January Agnes Blaik Indweller in Haddington born in the parish of Boulton and Elizabeth Golight, daughter to William Golight, born in this parish being both accused and imprisoned as guilty of lewdness and uncleanliness with many dferent persons. Elizabeth Golight confesses that since Michaelmas last she has been guilty of uncleanliness with several persons and Agnes Blaikie confesses she was formerly convict of uncleanliness and that she was a bad woman ndash But not of late. But acknowledges she lives in a house alone and that there has been dragoons with her in the house. Which being considered by the Magistrates they find Elizabeth Golight is a vicious strumpet and to their certain information Agnes Blaik is a vicious lewd woman. And therefore they ordain both the said Elizabeth Golight and Agnes Blaik be taken to the cross Friday next with the officers and Hangman and there to stand sometime with a paper or sack of theirhellip donating their crime and thereafter be conveyed tohellip with beat of the drum and to be banished forever out of the borough with certicationever they or either one of themto or be seen in this burgh they shall be whipped by the hangman.Signed Andrew Dixon, George Cunningham, Bailies.But it seems the harsh punishment did not prevent them from ing to the town, for Ros came across another two entries:th May Appeared with Janet Golight her mother Elizabeth for repeating acts of lewdness and stealing from Robina Mucklersquos shop. Both found guilty and sent to the House of Correction in Edinburgh to be kept at hard work for  years. Should be whipped by the hangman and burnt on the cheek.th June Agnes Black ed to buy a gown for herself and so was sentenced to be whipped through the town and banished.Ros later sent me her transcriptions, saying: ldquoI love the way Agnes confessed she lsquowas a bad woman ndash but not of latersquo. It rings out over the centuries. And I have a definite dislike for the bailies pronouncing on the lsquovicious strumpetrsquo and the lsquovicious lewd womanrsquo, particularly as there is no mention of any man being named, despite the men being lsquoto their certain informationrsquo!Ros had emailed me the transcription in January  and wrote to me: ldquoI thought it was a tale worth telling and you could weave your magic on it and perhaps find a happy ending.To my regret, I only came across this email last week, as it had somehow remained unopened in my inbox for over two years. I admit to being technically useless on computer matters!But a happy ending  Itrsquos clear both Agnes and Elizabeth had very harsh lives, and on the surface there seems little scope for a truly happy ending.The description of them is misogynistic and full of double standards, as Ros pointed out.So what were these women really like  The writer tries to paint a picture of awful human beings, but the image of poor Agnes secretly creeping back into town, no doubt in a state of desperation, to ldquobuy herself a gown and then being whipped as a punishment gives a dferent story. The punishments for both women are barbaric and utterly unjust.Then I realised that there was a happy ending. That happy ending was in late , when Ros walked into the John Gray Centre and found out about Agnes and Elizabeth. She read the account with human understanding and saw through the prejudice to glimpse at the women themselves and understand just how wrongly they had been treated and judged. And so she spoke up for them and gave them a place in history, while turning the judgment on their accusers.Thatrsquos a happy ending I know Ros would have liked.

title: east-lothian-surfer-features-new-advert-carling
story: The five surfers ndash aged between  and  ndash took on the waves for a national advertising campaign for the beer giant called lsquoMade Localrsquo.Retired roofer Ian McKay, from Whitekirk, was joined by Jason Burnett, Douglas Brown and Dee Ripol, all from Edinburgh, with filming taking place over two days nearly two years ago. Rod Wallace was also present.A film crew set up base for the advert, which can be viewed online, at Pease Bay, about two miles from the East Lothian county boundary, with impressive surfing conditions helping to create a stunning advert.Jason, , told the Courier: ldquoWe were approached by Carling, who found us through social media.ldquoThey were impressed by how wersquore making it where wersquore from ndash my surfboard-making business for the local community in particular struck a chord. Our story inspired Carling to feature us in its Made Local advert with the aim of encouraging more people to follow their passions in their local area.ldquoThe Made Local Fund is Carlingrsquos multi-million-pound commitment over the next three years to those things that matter most to local communities, just like us and our surfing.ldquoCarling have recently supported me in providing funding for the materials needed to hand craft and design some surfboards which will be donated to the Scottish Surfing Federation.ldquoThese bespoke surfboards will be provided free to people who want to try surfing for the first time.Ian, , has been surfing with friends for more than  years, with the sport gaining popularity across Scotland.And while surfing hot spots include Hawaii, Calornia and Australiarsquos Gold Coast, East Lothian was proving popular as well.Jason, who makes surfboards, said the county was an ideal place for them to get into the water.He said: ldquoCold water surfing in East Lothian is hardcore!ldquoIn winter the waves are big, the weather is cold and the sea is colder, but we donrsquot let that put us off ndash we donrsquot care how cold it is.ldquoWersquore proud to surf in all weathers and all year round. Nothing stops us.ldquoSurfing these waters is also a big social thing for us too.ldquoThe friendships we have forged through years of surfing in these freezing cold waters still stand strong today.ldquoWe have surfed all over the world, but no matter where the sport has taken us, coming back to home waters is where our hearts lie.ldquoThe local beaches along the East Lothian coastline are really special and have some of the most stunning scenery in the world.The video can be viewed by going to Carlingrsquos YouTube page.

title: pencaitland-pub-winton-arms-sale
story: The Winton Arms, on the villagersquos Main Street, is being advertised online for pound,.The bar, which has an outdoor seated area and a pool room, is owned by pub company Punch.Andy Spencer, managing director, said: ldquoWe have made the decision that The Winton Arms no longer fits in the long-term plans for our pub estate. We have recently put the freehold opportunity on the market to sell as a pub.ldquoThe Winton Arms remains open and serving the local community as normal.

title: vigilante-leaving-soiled-nappies-bags-dog-poo-bid-keep-youths-woodland-spot
story: The unusual tactic at the area known as The Jam Pot ndash within Lochend Woods ndash was revealed by police in Dunbar.Constable Gavin Ross said: ldquoSomebody has been disposing lots of bags of dog poo in that area, I think as a deterrent, and used nappies as well, which is not good.ldquoIf the youths are going to go somewhere, which they are, then it is an area we could keep an eye on them.The officer described the area of land, off Kellie Road, and what was happening.He said: ldquoIt is bare ground apart from the fact it is covered in broken glass. There are fallen trees lying there, which the kids use as benches.ldquoThere are dog faeces and nappies on the benches and the floor there.ldquoIt is  per cent deliberate ndash somebody is deterring the kids from going there.The police officer was not happy with the tactic being used and said it was moving the youngsters where, including to the nearby play park at Ashfield.Reports of more than  youths gathering at the playpark were raised by members of the public at the townrsquos community and police partnershipmeetings towards the end of last year.At that time, stories of underage drinking in the park, as well as nearby homes also being damaged, were highlighted.PC Ross said: ldquoWe had been discouraging them from going to the playpark at Ashfield.ldquoIt is a public area and they were drinking and it is where young children are going to play.ldquoIf there are going to be smashed bottles, I donrsquot want that in a playpark.ldquoWe have been moving them from there and explaining the reasons for it.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, was among those at the meeting in Dunbar Police Station.She described the dumping of nappies and dog faeces as ldquohorrible and said: ldquoI think it is actually grim and I cannot really imagine what kind of mind thinks like that.ldquoOne would have thoughtthere was a real anxiety about the behaviour of the children, first of all it could be reported to the police and they could come and attend to it ndash orit is possible for that person to identy the children and go speak to them ndash but the idea that you deliberately pollute a public space seems a very, very strange unsavoury tactic.

title: scottish-open-renaissance-club-attracts-record-attendance
story: Nearly , people attended the Aberdeen Standard Investments Scottish Open while the competition, which was played at The Renaissance Club, also produced its lowest score to par.Bernd Wiesberger was crowned the winner following three play-off holes at the course, near Dirleton.He carded  under ndash which was matched by Benjamin Hebert and was the lowest score to par since the competition began in .Early figures suggest , attended the competition, up by nearly , from last yearrsquos tournament at Gullane Golf Club.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said that the tournament had proven ldquoa great success, with analysis to be carried out to look at its economic benefits.She said: ldquoThe Aberdeen Standard Investments Scottish Open was a great success, with record attendance figures of almost , who enjoyed world-class golf at The Renaissance Club.ldquoThe economic boost to East Lothian of this tournament and the forthcoming Aberdeen Standard Investments Ladies Scottish Open will be independently assessed and we look forward to seeing the results of that assessment later this year.ldquoIt was also a successful event for the many local food and drink suppliers who won contracts to supply the event.Neil Christison, VisitScotland regional director, felt the eventrsquos success was another great advert for the county as a golfing destination.He said: ldquoThe Scottish Open at The Renaissance Club was a great success, attracting visitors from across the world and showcasing East Lothian as a top destination for international events to a global audience.ldquoAnd there is still more to come for East Lothian this summer, with Ladies Scottish Open and Scottish Senior Open taking place in the region in the coming weeks.ldquoThe staging of these high-profile sporting events has an immense impact on tourism in East Lothian and surrounding areas, attracting golf fans from across Scotland and beyond.ldquoWith its range of  courses, high-quality accommodation, food and drink, and visitor attractions, East Lothian really does live up to its name as Scotlandrsquos Golf Coast.ldquoGolf is a vital part of the visitor economy, with the ripple effect felt in shops, hotels, restaurants and a wide iety of other businesses across the region.ldquoGolf tourism is worth poundm to the country annually ndash and around pound.million to East Lothian alone.Cast a great lightGael Pollitt, chair of Scotlandrsquos Golf Coast, felt that the event had cast the county in a great light.He said: ldquoThere is no doubt that the hosting of the ASI Scottish Open on Scotlandrsquos Golf Coast again showed East Lothian to be a golfing Mecca and the live TV streaming of the championship throughout the world will surely boost interest in all the county has to offer.ldquoDuring commentary and written reports there were frequent references made to the wide range of golf courses and the ersity of accommodation options available.ldquoOn our stand in the championship village, it was very encouraging to hear the comments from visitors who had travelled considerable distances of their desire toand play courses that they had not previously appreciated, as well as visit the many other tourist attractions in East Lothian.ldquoIn three weeksrsquo time, it is the turn of the ladies to compete on Scotlandrsquos Golf Coast, when again many of the top players in the world will be present.North Berwick Coastal ward councillors Jim Goodfellow and Jeremy Findlay also felt the event had gone well.Mr Goodfellow said: ldquoThe Scottish Open has been another success for East Lothian tourism and has brought positive worldwide exposure for the county and economic benefit for local businesses.ldquoWe were lucky with the weather and the use of The Renaissance course minimising local traffic disruption.ldquoThe credit for the smooth running of the event must go to our council officers and the event organisers.Mr Findlay added: ldquoIt was a great event for East Lothian and showcases Scotlandrsquos Golf Coast, which is now the premier golfing location in Scotland.Councillor Jane Henderson, a ward colleague, agreed that the event appeared to have gone smoothly but she questioned what impact it had had on local businesses over the four days.The councillor noted that a number of businesses were very quiet during the tournament but acknowledged that the success of the competition could leave a positive long-term impact.She said: ldquoYou have to look at both sides and that is definitely my stance.ldquoIn the shorter term, people have bills and rent to pay and are running businesses.ldquoIt is alright for tourism and economic development to say the long-term impact will pay off in East Lothian.Businesses painted a mixed picture when it came to the impact of the tournament.Chris Hansen, owner of The Open Arms in Dirleton, was among those enjoying a fruitful week.He said: ldquoIt was a good week. The place was maybe a little bit quieter during the day when it was centred on the golf course.ldquoIn general, we were quite lucky with the weather.Gullanersquos Co-op store was also affected by the tournament, with traffic encouraged to avoid the village.Greg Millar, store manager, said: ldquoWe actually did better than what I thought we would but didnrsquot do as well as the business thought we would,that makes sense.ldquoIt could have been a lot betterthe traffic was erted through Gullane.Meanwhile, Tricia Johnstone, of Fenton Barns Farm Shop and Cafe, felt the event had a detrimental impact on their business.She said: ldquoIt damages business more than increases it.ldquoA lot of people just stay away.But Carol Millar, from The Golfers Rest on North Berwick High Street, said the pub was ldquobusy, adding: ldquoOn Friday and Saturday it was absolutely crazy. I donrsquot knowit is because we are called The Golfers Rest but it was quite busy.Tom Drysdale, chairman of Gullane Area Community Council, which also covers Dirleton, said the impact in terms of flow of people and traffic through the village was ldquonot very signicant.He said: ldquoI went on Saturday and Sunday and there was a wonderful atmosphere. I think it was a very good thing for the area.ldquoI think it would be fair to say it did not have a major impact on the village of Dirleton itself but, speaking as a community council for the other areas, it was a big event for us and brought a tremendous number of visitors to the area and I think that has a long-term legacy.

title: provost-flies-flag-east-lothian-festival-france
story: John McMillan, Provost of East Lothian, was carrying the Haddington flag through Aubigny-sur-Nere on Sunday afternoon during a parade in the Franco-Scottish Festival.The Haddington and Lammermuir ward councillor was flanked by his son Douglas and brother Jim, who were carrying the town keys.Mr McMillan is visiting the town on a family holiday and was joined there by Haddington Pipe Band.He the Courier: ldquoIt was quite a long parade and I thought I really should be flying the flag.ldquoEverybody in the pipe band played tremendously over the weekend.ldquoI am here on holiday but was asked to open the festival and the flag was here.ldquoI had been given the keys to the town on Friday evening at a formal ceremony and it was a real honour to march behind the pipe band as they were leading the parade.Liz McDougall, the pipe band quartermaster, carried the flag at the morning ceremony at the war memorial alongside the townrsquos veterans.A copy of last weekrsquos Courier ndash wrapped in tartan and red, white and blue ribbon ndash was also presented to the townrsquos archive.A link between the East Lothian town and Aubigny, which is between Orleans and Bourges in central France, dates back to .Residents of each town have regularly made the trip to their counterparts.The twinning links are evident throughout Haddington, with a sign outside Haddington Corn Exchange bearing the street name Place drsquoAubigny, and the townrsquos leisure centre also named after the French settlement.Mr McMillan explained the importance of the relationship between the two countries and the two towns.He said: ldquoI think the French are aware of the Auld Alliance but in Aubigny it is particularly alive and remembered with links to the Hundred Yearsrsquo War, when a Scottish lord rescued the town from the English and gave wood to rebuild the town.

title: bid-name-new-sports-pavilion-39-unofficial-mayor-north-berwick-39
story: Labour Party stalwart and former vice-chairman of Heart of Midlothian FC Pilmar Smith passed away in November last year.Now, plans are being drawn up to pay tribute to Mr Smith, who was , including the idea of a plaque in his honour at a new sports pavilion.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, who represents North Berwick, said: ldquoThere has been a move within the town to have some sort of commemorative something around the town.ldquoThe proposal at the moment is that there is a new sports pitch being built up at the new housing by the high school.ldquoThere is to be a pavilion there and the proposal is we name it the Pilmar Smith Pavilion and a plaque goes up to that effect.ldquoIt would probably mention his connections with football over the years and North Berwick.The pitch, which is to the west of Law Primary School, is not yet playable, with the new surface needing time to bed in..However, it is expected to open later this year, with planning permission already in place for the pavilion.East Lothian Council is looking to appoint a contractor for the pavilion, with work expected to start in November and be complete by spring next year.Mr Smith was raised in Edinburgh and spent several decades as a bookmaker.A Hearts fan all his le, he became vice-chairman of the Tynecastle club in , during which time they twice finished as runners-up in the Scottish Football League Premier Division.He held the position for  years before stepping down following a change of ownership.Mr Smith was chairman of East Lothian Constituency Labour Party until about  and spent more than a decade as chairman of Lothian Buses.Mr Goodfellow previously expressed his gratitude to Mr Smith in helping him to be elected as the first-ever Labour councillor for the area.He said: ldquoIt would be an excellent tribute to someone who contributed a lot to North Berwick during his time here.Judy Lockhart, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, gave her backing to the idea.She told the Courier: ldquoThe community council were very saddened to hear of the passing of Pilmar Smith in November last year.ldquoPilmar had lived in North Berwick for around  years and was as well-known as he was well loved.ldquoOne can only imagine how long it took Pilmar to walk from one end of High Street to the other when you consider that almost every person he passed would stop him for a lsquoquick chatrsquo!ldquoFollowing requests from residents, the community council agreed that something was required to commemorate Pilmar and local elected councillor Jim Goodfellow suggested that the new football pavilion might be the ideal site.ldquoGiven that Pilmar was a lelong fan of Hearts Football Club, where he also served as a director and vice-chairman for more than a decade, this seemed a fitting tribute.ldquoThe community council have since allocated funding to purchase a plaque and, with great fondness, look forward to naming the new football pavilion the lsquoPilmar Smith Pavilionrsquo in his memory.

title: tranent-minister-rubs-shoulders-royalty-garden-party-palace-holyroodhouse
story: The Rev Erica Wishart, minister at Tranent Parish Church, was thrilled to be invited to the royal garden party in Edinburgh this year after being nominated by Michael Williams, Lord Lieutenant of East Lothian.She said: ldquoIt was a real privilege to be there, in the presence of Her Majesty the Queen along with Prince Andrew, Prince Edward and Princess Anne. My husband, the Rev Bill Wishart [minister at St Martinrsquos Parish Church in the Magdalene area of Edinburgh], came with me as my lsquoplus onersquo and we had a lovely afternoon walking around the gardens of Holyroodhouse in the sunshine.ldquoWe couldnrsquot get near enough to see the royal family close up, but we did manage to photograph the Queen from afar as she paused on the steps for the national anthem it was easy to spot her as she was wearing a bright salmon pink coat and hat.The royal family hosts four garden parties a year ndash three at Buckingham Palace and one at the Palace of Holyroodhouse ndash with more than , people attending in total. They are designed to recognise and reward the public service of the attendees.Erica added: ldquoThere were a few bands playing music in dferent parts of the gardens, which added atmosphere to the event.ldquoWe enjoyed the tea, sandwiches and cakes in the tea tent: I had been told to expect tiny ones but actually they were a decent size.There were cucumber sandwiches ndash of course! ndash and the egg sandwiches had mint leaves in them which gave an unusual taste, quite refreshing. We also had fruit tarts, Victoria sponge and macaroons, all very tasty.ldquoYou couldnrsquot miss the royal tea tent ndash it was the one with the crown on top ndash but we couldnrsquot get near it, the crowds were so big.ldquoIt was fun wandering around seeing all the dferent outfits, unorms and hats. Someone asked uswe had met anyone of note and I replied: lsquoYes, Billrsquos aunty Isabelle and her pal Dot!rsquo They were the first familiar faces we saw in the crowd.ldquoThatrsquos one of the good things about the garden party: people of all ages, from all walks of le are invited, so therersquos a feeling of inclusivity.ldquoIt was a grand day out and I have written to the Lord Lieutenant to thank him for nominating me to attend on behalf of Tranent Parish Church.

title: dunbar-grandmother-39-s-abseil-memory-youngster
story: Heather Stenhouse joined more than  other people in abseiling from the Forth Bridge last Saturday.The grandmother, who has had two knee transplants and recently lost more than eight stones in weight, abseiled from Barns Ness Lighthouse, near Dunbar, last year before taking on the -ft drop in South Queensferry in aid of the Edinburgh Childrenrsquos Hospital Charity.Heather, who raised nearly pound,, said the charity had been a great help to the family of young David Watson who was diagnosed with a neuroblastoma ndash a type of cancer that forms in certain types of nerve tissue ndash before passing away aged just four years old.She said: ldquoWe have got  grandchildren and we have needed the charity ourselves.ldquoWhen David was bad, they were so good and they were beside us every step of the way. They supported us, kept us in the loop and I just think we all need the Sick Kids ndash either for our own children or somebody  we know.ldquoThe money goes straight to looking after the children.ldquoThey see the child, they donrsquot see the patient ndash that is the bit that is so important.ldquoAt the end of the day, they are still children.Heatherrsquos daughter Amanda is close friends with the Watson family, who live in Haddington.The two families grew close together and Heather said David became like one of her own while he was undergoing treatment for the condition, which is one of the most common types of cancer in childhood.Heather, who is also a member of Dunbarrsquos UNICEF committee, described the youngster as ldquofull of le and a character in his own right.She added: ldquoWhen he was diagnosed with the neuroblastoma, he just took it all in his stride. Any picture of him, he is always laughing and smiling. He kept us all going at times.Since Davidrsquos death in November , Heather has regularly raised funds for the charity as well as collecting selection boxes each year in Davidrsquos memory to ensure each child in hospital and their siblings get a Christmas treat.The florist, who works at Megrsquos Flowers on Dunbarrsquos West Port, told the Courier she had lost eight stone in  weeks ahead of the abseil after joining Slimming World.She said: ldquoThe abseil went fine. I have had two new knees and lost eight stone to do this and it was amazing.ldquoWith the new knees, I thought it would be dficult but it was a lot easier than I expected.ldquoAt  years old,I can do it anybody can do it.To sponsor Heather, go to justgiving fundraising heathersmadhatters

title: work-long-awaited-port-seton-sports-hall-set-start-soon
story: The much-anticipated hall has been in the pipeline for several years and plans for the expansion were lodged with East Lothian Council more than two years ago.The local authority says that contracts for the work are expected to be awarded this month, with contractors expected to start on site in September.The new hall will allow the centre to offer more activities and a wider range of sports than ever before, including basketball, badminton, tennis and football.It will also allow centre regulars such as East Lothian Gymnastics Association the chance to train with a proper run-up to their apparatus.The new hall, which will be an extension to the main building, will measure  metres by  metres and also includes storage areas.There will be a new lobby created to link the hall to the cafe area of the main centre building and it will provide capacity for more classes to be held in the centre.It is being built to the west of the current building, with plans to move the childrenrsquos play area, re-siting it beside the new hall, in an area which will be better positioned for parents to keep an eye on youngsters.A report to the council revealed there had been a delay on the work as the ldquotechnical specs were revised to bring it within budget.A council spokesperson said: ldquoThe main elements of our investment at Port Seton Community Centre to provide a new sports hall with provision for gymnastics remains unchanged.ldquoIn order to secure best value and deliver the project within budget, we have revisited the technical specications for the project.ldquoWe now anticipate awarding the contract for works in late July with contractors starting on site in September.ldquoWe are working with the centrersquos management group to keep them involved as the project progresses.

title: east-lothian-school-pupils-help-create-oor-wullie-sculptures
story: Schools across the county took part in the Oor Wullie Big Bucket Trail challenge to come up with their own unique design for the famous comic strip character.Their work supports the first national arts trail on Scotland, which has seen about  larger-than-le Oor Wullie sculptures unveiled in and around cities across the country.As previously reported by the Courier, East Lothian has its very own Oor Wullie sculpture at the Scottish Seabird Centre, North Berwick, as part of the Edinburgh trail, and Law Primary School teacher Valerie Duncan was chosen as one of the artists invited to decorate one of the public artworks.Her design, entitled Natural Healing, is on display at Waverley Bridge in Edinburgh.Valerie, who is also a volunteer with Girlguiding East Lothian, said she was inspired by nature to create her Oor Wullie.She said: ldquoHaving been successfully selected to design and paint one of the Oor Wullie sculptures, I spent a week in April bringing my design to le.ldquoI had some aching muscles and very sore knees after crawling around the larger-than-le sculpture to make sure I hadnrsquot missed any bits.ldquoMy design is inspired by the healing properties found in plants and the positive impact nature can have on peoplersquos wellbeing.The public are being encouraged to download a mobile app to follow their local trails and vote for their favourite sculptures.Donations and funds raised by auctioning off the work at the end of the trail will be split between three charities: Edinburgh Childrenrsquos Hospital Charity, Glasgow Childrenrsquos Hospital Charity and the ARCHIE Foundation.While Valerie joined the other artists creating the public sculptures, primary schools and nursery classes were able to apply for a mini sculpture of their own to decorate and came up with a wide range of ideas and costumes for Oor Wullie.Gullane Primary Schoolrsquos nursery classes worked together on Gracious Greg from Gullane ndash inspired by their learning on Holi festival, their statue was decorated with colourful handprints and fingerprints to celebrate love, kindness and friendship.Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary School, Musselburgh, created a design inspired by their home town dubbed Oor Mussy Wullie, while Preston Tower Primary School in Prestonpans gave their sculpture an environment theme as Oor Earth Wullie, highlighting the importance of caring for the planet and not dropping litter.Pupils came up with lots of ideas for their decorations in competitions across the schools.At Cockenzie Primary School, Natasha OrsquoConnor, depute headteacher, said it had been impossible to choose a winning design from youngsters so they combined them.She said: ldquoThere were so many fantastic entries that we ended up doing a combined design of a number of entries.ldquoIt mainly features a sea and fishing boat pattern on his dungarees with a sea glass bucket and a picture of the power station on the base.At Windygoul Primary School, P pupil Ryan Fergusonrsquos vision of a Posh Wullie, looking more like the Beanorsquos Lord Snooty than a member of The Broons, won the seal of approval.While Longniddry, Aberlady and Haddington Primary Schools all produced sculptures.Pear Tree Nursery in Haddington produced a Porky Fae Pear Tree sculpture and Sandcastle Playgroup in Port Seton created Oor Hands of FriendshipWallyford Primary Schoolrsquos Wullie WOWSERwas a team effort.Lindsey Barley, depute headteacher said: ldquoAll the classes came up with their own ideas and when we came together to discuss them we found many of the ideas were the same so we worked together to create a plan.ldquoOne of our staff members, Mrs Fiddler, is a talented artist and she worked with the children to turn their ideas into a design, which incorporates many of the themes from the schoolrsquos badge. Every class had some time painting the statue. He was finally nished then shown to all the boys and girls and parents. We are all very proud of the end result.All the childrenrsquos work can be seen in displays across Edinburgh at the Portrait Gallery, Museum of Childhood and Ocean Terminal.Sandcastlersquos sculpture is on show at Jenners store.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, cabinet member for education, said: ldquoIrsquom so impressed with the dferent approaches that all of the schools have taken when designing their Oor Wullie statues. Many have used mots personal to their school and area, adding a touch of East Lothian to this much-loved character.ldquoItrsquos great that East Lothian schools have been so involved and Irsquom sure all of the statues will be admired by everyone who sees them in high-profile venues. Most importantly, it will raise funds for a fantastic cause.ldquoCongratulations to everyone who has taken part.

title: jennifer-maciver-positive-pathway-parenthood
story: For some, surrogacy ndashwhen a woman carries and gives birth to a baby for another person or couple ndashis the only option.The number of people applying to the courts to be formally recognised as the parents of a child following a surrogacy arrangement has increased across the UK in recent years reflecting a welcome change in societyrsquos views on the lsquotraditionalrsquo family.Jenner Maciver, head of family law at law firm Gillespie Macandrew welcomes a review of the existing legal framework around surrogacy.ldquoItrsquos very much a live and current issue and we are pleased to see the Scottish Law Commission and Law Commission of England and Wales have been jointly appraising existing legislation and have published proposals for consultation. The current law around surrogacy is outdated and doesnrsquot reflect modern medical advances or changes in social attitudes. Surrogacy is a particularly sensitive and emotionally demanding process for everyone involved so we welcome anything which simplies or modernises the legislation. A draft report is anticipated, followed by draft legislation by  but their proposals offer a clear indication about the recommended direction of travel, she says.Parental ordersCurrently, the surrogate, and her spouse ndash she has one ndash are the legal parents of the child at birth and their names are noted on the birth certicate. The intended parents must make an application to the court for a parental order to be recognised as the childrsquos parents, with the legal rights and responsibilities this entails. This can take around six months to process which she points out can pose several potential problems. The first is that while the intended parents are socially and psychologically the parents, that doesnrsquot match the legal position, which can cause identity problems. On the flip side, the surrogate doesnrsquot normally view herself as the childrsquos mother, but the law does. Secondly,the child needs medical care during the first six months of their le the intended parents will likely not have any legal standing to take medical decisions about the young child in their care, which is not on any view a good situation for the child.ldquoAt the moment there is a considerable gap between peoplersquos expectations and the law and signicant potential for misunderstandings. This is not a positive environment in which to welcome a child and we are pleased to see this being tackled as part of the review, says Maciver.She explains that the Law Commissionsrsquo lsquonew pathwayrsquo will have several positive outcomes: it will allow intended parents to become the legal parents from birth in some cases remove of the need for a genetic link between the intended parents and the child in some cases establish a new regulator for surrogacy create a register to allow those born of surrogacy arrangements to access information and for international surrogacy arrangements help those who have a child abroad to bring their child back to the UK with less red tape.The new framework, she says will set out proactive measures including ndashintroducing pre-conception safeguards that are built in before the baby is conceived to help to avoid problems later in the process. ldquoThe proposal is that before the child is conceived there must be a written agreement between the surrogate and the parent, an independent assessment of the childrsquos welfare, the intended parents and the surrogate are all bound to take independent legal advice so that they understand the process, they are all medically screened and criminal checks are carried out, she explains.The intended parents and the surrogate are also required to go to implications counselling to help establish the foundation for an appropriate and positive relationship.Which all sounds like an onerous process ndashbut itrsquos one which Maciver believes will actually signicantly enhance the current situation. ldquoItrsquos more proactive and sees the introduction of meaningful safeguards ndashwhich will hopefully reduce the problems that can sometimes arise after the birth of a child and provide clarity for those entering into a surrogacy arrangement exactly whatrsquos expected of them.The overseas optionOwing to the restrictions on commercial surrogacy in the UK and the dficulty in finding willing surrogates some people choose to go to countries where commercial surrogacy is legally possible ndashwhich often leads to further complications when trying to bring the baby back to the UK.Overseas situations, she says, account for approximately half of surrogacies and they will still have to apply for a parental order, which is also getting an overhaul. For example, currently the intended parents have to apply for that within six months of the child being born, which is a relatively narrow window. The proposal is remove that time limit. They are also proposing changes to make it easier and quicker to get a passport or visa to bring the child to live with them in Scotland. Unlike other areas of family law in Scotland, , surrogacy is an area that has seen cultural attitudes change faster than legislation and Maciver believes that the Law Commissionsrsquo proposals are welcome, though not perfect.While commercial surrogacy is banned, reasonable payments are allowed, which leads to grey areas which the proposals donrsquot yet address, for example, what is reasonable and what strays into lsquopaymentrsquo ldquoThe law in this instance is very dficult to apply, says Maciver. If the payment is higher than reasonably anticipated what options does the court have  There has so far been no refusal of a parental order based on the level of payment but itrsquos probably the most contentious area in the consultation. Itrsquos one in which people hold strong opposing views and so the Law Commissions have canvassed opinion about how these limitations should be set and enforced.Single parentsIn the meantime, though she is encouraged by the fact that in January the law was changed following a challenge to the Human Rights Act  meaning that single parents can now apply for a parental order. ldquoThis was the single most urgent issue: previously only married couples, civil partners, cohabitants or people in other enduring relationships could apply.And the future  Maciver says that there are dfering views about the best route forward ndashand of course the proposed changes are still at consultation stage. But she believes that the new pathwayis long overdue and will have very positive effect, improving the way that surrogacy works and better protecting the interests of surrogates, intended parents and ultimately the children involved.Which is a community whose numbers are fast increasing.Jenner Maciver, is head of family law at law firm Gillespie Macandrew, whocombine specialist, practical advice with a responsive, supportive and discrete service.For more information abouthow Gillespie Macandrew can help please visitwww.gillespiemacandrew

title: first-look-haddingtons-newly-refurbished-swimming-pool

title: prestonpans-schools-pupils-aiming-get-involved-community
story: St Gabrielrsquos RC Primary School sent P representatives Olivia Lees, Ciaran Kelly, Fraser Graham, and Daniel McCabe, all , to speak to Prestonpans Community Council about their work and the potential involvement of much younger participants.The school was recently successful in achieving its UNICEF Rights Respecting School gold award, which means that it had proved that it incorporates the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child into the school through both teaching and actions.It now aims to take this further and bring this ethos into the surrounding community.The children were given the chance of addressing the meeting, which included ward councillors Fiona OrsquoDonnell and Neil Gilbert, to ask questions and discuss the best ways to engage young people with what is going on in the community and to ensure their input is noted.The children asked about the plans for the site of the former Cockenzie Power Station and whether more activities for young people such as Rainbows and Scouts could be introduced to the areaWhen addressing the councillors and community councillors, Daniel, a house captain from St Gabrielrsquos, said: ldquoItrsquos important for us at this stage to know what our future is going to hold, and to try and make a dference when and where we can.ldquoTo be involved in the community council in some way would be fantastic, as it would give us comfort to know that the community is being taken care of, as well as what decisions were being made that might affect us.It was decided that the community council would send the agenda for each meeting to the school a few days before the meeting took place so that the children could see it and comment on any issues being raised.The community council said in a statement: ldquoWe would like to thank the four fantastic pupils from St Gabrielrsquos Primary School who attended the community council.ldquoIt was so refreshing to have such polite and knowledgeable young people along to one of our meetings to share their opinions and views on our agenda topics and ask the questions they feel most relevant to their lives.ldquoWe look forward to welcoming them along to future meetings and collaborating with them on the issues that affect all of us living in Prestonpans.

title: fringe-sea-q-amp-professor-ben-garrod
story: The professor is a broadcaster, author and evolutionary biologist at the University of East Anglia and has done a QA to gear people up for his show.Were you interested in dinosaurs as a child Not just dinosaurs, but anything prehistoric. My first fossil find was on a beach near where I grew up. I was five years old and was on a day out with mum and dad. We wound the fossilised shell of a belemnite, which was a relative of the squid we see alive today. It was over  million years old and that blew my socks off! It made me start questioning where all these ancient animals went, why we donrsquot have dinosaurs around now and how the planet could be so old. Obviously, I loved dinosaurs too and loved reading about them in all my old books, imagining what it would be like to see a T. rex walking through my garden.Why are so many children obsessed with them So many people are obsessed with dinosaurs, both kids and adults alike. Itrsquos hard to pin down exactly why we love them so much and I think itrsquos for a few dferent reasons. First of all, when we are growing up we love to learn lots of facts about things . . . the speed of fast cars maybe or the size of planets in space. Dinosaurs are the same and we love to learn how fast an Allosaurus could run or discover which was the biggest. I also think they inspire us through being so big, fierce and scary but we feel safe because we know dinosaurs can never hurt us because theyrsquore all extinct You are described as an lsquoevolutionary biologistrsquo ndash what exactly does that entail Irsquom a Professor of Evolutionary Biology at the University of East Anglia. Sounds fancy doesnrsquot it but itrsquos the coolest job in the world. The lsquoBiologyrsquo bit just means I get to study all sorts of le ndash it could be anything that is alive or was ever alive, so anything from a chimpanzee or a Troodon, to a butterfly or monkey puzzle tree. The lsquoEvolutionrsquo bit means I study how these living organisms change and adapt over time. How does a changing marine environment affect sharks or how does predation from birds affect camouflage in lizards  All these changes are down to evolution. I study le and how it changes, and I share that knowledge with as many people as possible. Being a scientist means you get to study cool stuff like this every single day.How many books have you written I have written six books so far. My series lsquoSo You Think You Know About Dinosaursrsquo are pretty cool, evenI do say so myself. I wanted them to be the most up to date dinosaur books in  million years and although I wanted them to be enjoyed by young readers, the content should be the same as that which I teach to university students. I know young readers really want to learn and we donrsquot need to dumb stuff down, but with a few more cartoons, quizzes and examples, I think they can be enjoyed by young and older readers. Each book focuses on just one species and it was so hard to pick just six. Eventually, I chose Tyrannosaurus, Triceratops, Stegosaurus, Diplodocus, Velociraptor and Spinosaurus. Therersquos something there for everyone and between them, these dinosaurs really tell the complete story.Herersquos something we all want to know ndash which dinosaur would have been the most dangerous to humans Arrrrrgh, this is such a tough question. Is one T. rex worse than one hundred velociraptors  Even something like a Triceratops could have been deadly. Itrsquos easier to say which dinosaurs would have been safe . . . there wouldnrsquot have been many. Stegosaurus had tail spikes around one metre long, Ankylosaurus had a tail club which could have destroyed a car and Argentinosaurus weighed so much that yoursquod definitely want to be stepped on. And theyrsquore just the herbivores! Imagine what the meat-eaters would have done.And which was the very biggest Ah, this is a question I get asked a lot. There has been huge debate and even some arguments between scientists. Irsquom not going to give it away ndash yoursquoll have to come to my show and find out. Irsquoll give you a clue . . . itrsquos not the one you think it is.What dinosaurs would have roamed around this country many millions of years ago This is a really hard one to answer for each show right now. We had so many prehistoric species that wersquore spoilt for choice now. We had giant sauropods up on the Western Isles in Scotland, early relatives of T. rex in Wales and even the fish-eating Baryonyx on the Isle of Wight. There are also discoveries of marine reptiles such as the dolphin-like ichthyosaurs and super-predator pliosaurs all around our coastlines all the time. The best thing to do is get out there and go have a look or visit your local museum and discover what used to swim, fly, run and plod around near where you live, millions of years ago.Were numbers declining before whatever environmental catastrophe wiped them out about m years ago and would they have become extinct naturally No, they werenrsquot. The Cretaceous period was the third major period of the dinosaurs and they were doing really well. Some of the most well-known dinosaurs were around right about the time when the asteroid struck. It was also the age of the titanosaurs ndash the biggest dinosaurs to ever live. If that asteroid hadnrsquot crashed into the sea just north of Mexico then in all likelihood, things might have been very dferent and you might really have had a Tyrannosaursus in your garden or a Protoceratops in your playground. But remember, the asteroid did not kill all the dinosaurs . . .Have you ever been on expeditions to find dinosaur remains and where are the places most likely to find them I have. My favourite was when I went with Sir David Attenborough to Argentina to film the discovery and excavation of a true dino giant. The great thing about loving dinosaurs and living in the British Isles is that we have so many fossils of dinosaurs and other prehistoric species. There are certain beaches and riversides famous for fossils and you have a very good chance of finding the fossil bones of a prehistoric marine reptile or shark teeth or ammonite shells. You always have to go with an adult and thoroughly plan your trip because fossil hunting can be dangerous but itrsquos so much fun.Do you identy at all with lsquodinosaur expertrsquo characters on film or television There have been some well-known characters on TV who study dinosaurs but usually theyrsquore rubbish. Look at Ross from Friends . . . Irsquom pretty sure he couldnrsquot tell the dference between the head and butt of a Dreadnoughtus. Characters like that donrsquot inspire me. Real scientists are much better and inspire me every day. The men and women who spend their lives digging up fossils and investigating how these animals and plants lived are much cooler than a TV character.

title: music-fan-kevin-proves-39-s-popmaster
story: Kevin OrsquoDonnell stole the show when he appeared on PopMaster on BBC Radio .A score of  out of  was enough to win the quiz on Ken Brucersquos show.Kevin, who runs his own joinery and garden business, told the Courier: ldquoIt was something that I always wanted to do.ldquoI am right into my music and PopMaster is probably the premier music quiz in Britain.The -year-oldrsquos opponent managed a score of , with Kevin declared the winner and receiving the prize of a digital speaker in the shape of an old-style microphone.The prize has taken pride of place in Kevinrsquos West Barns home, with dozens of people getting in touch with him to offer their congratulations since the show was broadcast.He said: ldquoI met Bruce Springsteen in  in Newcastle and I think this is not quite up there with that but it is not far off.The popular radio quiz has been running for a number of years and each contestant is asked  questions based on popular music from the s through to the present day.He said: ldquoI have listened to Ken Bruce for a good  or  years and the last couple of years I have tried to get on the show.ldquoMy kids have always been saying to me to go.ldquoMy son, Conor, is the lead guitarist in The Tesla Coils and we are always discussing and talking about music.The music fan, who spoke to the Courier as he was en route to see American rock legends Kiss perform at the SSE Hydro in Glasgow, played down his achievement and said the questions simply fell in his favour.ldquoYou can get a possible  points thatrsquos the maximum you can score, said Kevin. ldquoThat is based on  questions and it is just general music knowledge. It just depends onit is for you.ldquoAll my stuff is s and s music andthe questions had been about the year  I would have got five out of !ldquoIt is really luck andthe questions are for you ndash it just happened that the questions were from my era.

title: connor-farrell-barber-stars-scottish-open-golf-renaissance-club
story: Bernd Wiesberger, who won the tournament at The Renaissance Club earlier this month, was among the professionals putting their feet up for a moment and getting a trim from Connor Farrell.The barber, who lives in Pencaitland, cut the hair of more than  golfers, caddies, management teams and sponsors.He said: ldquoYou see all these players on the television and then you get to have a good chat with them face to face. It was a good experience.ldquoWe were there and set up on the Monday and were Tuesday through Thursday, Friday cutting hair.ldquoWe were only supposed to be there on Tuesday and Wednesday but we got asked to stay on.ldquoWe reckon we did anywhere between  and  haircuts and it was all just complimentary. We did Bernd Wiesberger, who won the tournament, and Matt Wallace, who is ranked rd in the world.ldquoThey were all good guys. They are just normal people at the end of the day.ldquoWe talked about ious things ndash they wanted to know about good places to go eat in Edinburgh, ious local spots and seemed to like East Lothian and Edinburgh in general.Other golfers stepping into the hot seat included Lee Slattery, who finished tied for ninth at the competition, and West Lothianrsquos Stephen Gallacher.Former Ross High School pupil Connor, who is the owner and barber at Chaps Barber in Newcraighall, revealed that although the haircuts were complimentary, the golfers did offer generous tips and said: ldquoThey were pretty good ndash I cannot complain.Connor, who has been a barber for the last  months, got the chance through a family connection.His older sister Christy, , is dating North Berwick golfer Grant Forrest, who finished tied for rd at the event.Connor, , who plays golf at Longniddry Golf Club, was able to cheer Grant on.He said: ldquoThe European Tour got involved with Grantrsquos management company Bounce Sports.ldquoFrom there, they got the ball in motion and all the logistics of it.ldquoThese things take massive planning to get things done and it was quite a y process.ldquoIt took about two or three months to get it all finalised.

title: plea-save-former-dolphin-hotel-s-late
story: New le could be breathed into the former Dolphin Hotel, which included a bar and lounge on the ground floor.The bar closed in February  but the upstairs, which was used as a hotel, has not been in use for nearly  years.Developer The Dolphin InnLtd wants to ensure the building, on Dunbarrsquos Queenrsquos Road, has a future.Plans have been lodged with East Lothian Council for a hostel, complete with reception and cafe, on the ground floor.Under the proposals, the first floor would have four bedrooms, with three shower rooms and a family suite. The second floor would feature six bedrooms, with four bath or shower rooms, and the top floor acting as a managerrsquos flat.The developer has highlighted the poor state of the building and said that the first and second floors were ldquoseriously affected by dry rot and are unsafe.A ldquopriority of repairing the building and eradicating the advancing dry rot has been identied, with the developer keen to bring the building back into use ldquobefore itrsquos too late.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, told the Courier she had previously seen inside the building and it was ldquoin a terrible state of repair.She said: ldquoAnybody that wants to come in and invest high-quality renovation in Dunbar is to be welcomed.ldquoIt is wonderful that the building, which is so prominent, is in line for a facelt.ldquoMy understanding is that the client group is going to be aimed at walkers and surfers and, again, that would be warmly welcomed.Attempts had previously been made to see the building re-open as a hotel. However, there was ldquono interest from potential developers.A design and access statement, which is included within the planning application, notes: ldquoItrsquos quite possible there has been no demand for this property to be retained as a hotel due to competition in the immediate vicinity, namely The Royal Mackintosh Hotel on Station Road and the Hillside Hotel on Queenrsquos Road.Two years ago, Dunbar Trout Farm Ltd, was given permission to transform the building. Those plans, approved in August , included the creation of two shops and four flats.However, the design and access statement reads: ldquoSince this permission was obtained, despite evidence of marketing, there has been insufficient interest for its use as shops and flats.ldquoOur clientsrsquo proposal is to redevelop the building for use as a hostel, providing accommodation to visitors to Dunbar, [primarily] those who would take part in the large number of outdoor activities available within the area.ldquoA small flat-roofed single-storey extension to the side is proposed to provide associated laundry room.

title: charlotte-cowan-takes-west-highland-way-memory-dad-kenny
story: Charlotte Cowan, from North Berwick is completing the walk, over five days, beginning on September .The -year-old is raising money for the townrsquos Edington Cottage Hospital, the place where her dad spent his last week.Charlottersquos dad Kenny Cowan was a support worker but a joiner by trade.Having lost her mother when she was a baby, Kenny raised Charlotte and her brother as a single parent with help from her gran and other family members.Charlotte, who lives on Lochbridge Road, had a great relationship with her dad.ldquoI was very close to him and practically attached to his hip when I was little, I would go everywhere with him, she told the Courier.ldquoHe was such a genuinely lovely guy, no one had a bad word to say about him.ldquoHe was a big personality in the community and was so well known and loved by many.Kenny played bowls for Dirleton Bowling Club, darts in North Berwick and was an honorary member at the townrsquos rugby club for  years.He had been suffering with a bad back on and off for years, thinking it was sciatica.But in October last year the pain was getting worse, to the point he struggled to get out of bed.Two months later, Kenny was told he had stage four aggressive cancer in his spine which had spread and nothing more could be done.It was his last wish to be able to go to Edington Cottage Hospital before he died.ldquoUp until his very last day he had lots of visitors in to see him, Charlotte said.ldquoI donrsquot think [the Edington] had ever known as many visitors.ldquoHe was laughing and joking and listening to his beloved Runrig.Kenny died on January , aged .Charlotte said: ldquoIt was extremely hard to lose him. It was one of the hardest things to go through but we take comfort in the fact he said he would always be watching over us and we had time at the end to get to say goodbye to him and he knew how loved he was.She has always wanted to walk the West Highland Way, being a lover of the outdoors and a keen hiker.ldquoFamily and work commitments always seemed to get in the way or I just thought it would be too expensive, she said.ldquoWhen my dad passed away, I wanted to do something for him it kind of gave me the push to stop putting it off and actually go for it.ldquoI just want to do something big in his honour.ldquoI would just like to raise a bit of money for the hospital as it is a huge part of our community.ldquoI went there with my children when they were young, my gran and nana spent time in there, and my dadrsquos dad spent his last days in there also.ldquoMy dad was so well looked after that I just wanted to give something back, say thank you for looking after my dad and the community so well.In terms of the walk she is excited about the challenge ahead, saying: ldquoI canrsquot wait for the walk, I know itrsquos going to be hard doing it over five days, which is an average of  miles a day. I just hope my feet are up to the challenge!Charlottersquos training is going well, having already completed practice walks on her route to check out the terrain.She has also walked up Ben Nevis and completed the Three Lochs Way in one day.ldquoI havenrsquot managed any consecutive days walks yet as with kids and work itrsquos not easy to fit in, she said. ldquoBut when schools go back in August, I will have a month to get last bits of training in. I do feel ready, though, definitely.ldquoA bad blister could ruin it all or an injury, but hopefully neither will happen. Irsquove just got to be as prepared as possible and keep my fingers crossed for the rest.Charlotte is not doing the challenge solo, with three walking friends going along with her.She said: ldquoSupport has been great, everyone is getting behind me and wishing me well and helping with sponsors. I really appreciate any money raised.She said a special thank you to her step-mum Heather, who met Kenny when Charlotte was  and later married him, saying: ldquoShe has been a huge support for me through everything and I really want to thank her for that.On her goals, she said: ldquoJust being able to give something back is all Irsquod like to achieve.ldquoWe will be celebrating with a big gin at the end! The feeling of achievement and knowing I will have done my dad proud will be the best feeling, though. He would probably have called me crazy for doing this as he did for a few things I had done, but I know hersquod be proud and thatrsquos all I want to do.Donate at uk.virginmoneygiving CharlotteCowan or via the sponsor sheet at Charlottersquos work, Smithrsquos Pharmacy, North Berwick High Street.

title: airshow-lifeboat-fete-gullane-games-musselburgh-festival-spott-fete
story: The Courier has put together a list of five of the top things to do over Saturday and Sunday.Whether it is planes, boats, horses or much more, there is plenty to keep everyone occupied.. Scotlands National AirshowBIG crowds are expected to flock to the National Museum of Flight at East Fortune on Saturday as Scotlandrsquos National Airshow takes place.And as well as all the aircraft initially announced, there are some exciting new additions to the line-up for the airshow, which takes place between am and pm.A Wildcat HMA  maritime attack helicopter,  Catalina flying boat and a  North American T Texan training aircraft are among the newbies.Joining them in their debut at the airshow are a Second World War Soviet Yakovlev Yak- fighter, a Westland Scout helicopter and a de Havilland Beaver utility aircraft.Also in the mix at the airshow are a Goodyear Corsair FG-D US wartime fighter bomber, Canadian T- Silver Star jet and an American P Thunderbolt Second World War fighter, while five members of the Wings Parachute Display Team drop in.As well as all the new additions, the aerial entertainment programme includes the RAFrsquos Supermarine Spitfire, Hawker Hurricane and Avro Lancaster from the RAF Battle of Britain Memorial Flight, as well as the modern-day Typhoon fighter jet.Aerobatic display team The Blades will take to the skies along with the AeroSuperBatics Wingwalkers, both performing some breathtaking tricks plus, much, much more.Tickets can be bought online, by calling    or on the gate on the day. Visit nms.ac.uk airshow for more details.. North Berwick Leboat FeteTHERErsquoS plenty of fun on offer this Saturday as North Berwick Leboat Fete takes place.The event, which runs between .pm and pm, starts with a parade along High Street before the crowning of this yearrsquos Leboat Queen, Theodora Nikolova, by Lady Dalrymple.The fete at Elcho Green and West Beach then opens at pm, with ious stalls and games on offer and a raffle.. Spott FeteAFTERNOON tea, games for children, stalls and music are all promised at Spott Village Fete.Teas are served in the village hall, with the event held on The Glebe from pm to pm.. Gullane GamesA WEEK of celebrations s to Gullane as the annual Gullane Games kicks off on Saturday and runs until next Saturday .The opening day is packed with sport ndash featuring golf, football and hockey.The under-srsquo golf competition starts at am on the childrenrsquos course.Football for under-s begins at pm at Memorial Park and P- hockey gets under way at .pm on the astroturf.Sunday sees a village treasure hunt from pm at the Mallard Hotel. Entry is pound per team, with maximum of five members per team children in primary school must be accompanied by an adult.. Musselburgh FestivalMUSSELBURGH festival is well under way, and there is still much to look forward to with fairground rides, fancy dress, a raft race and parades still on the horizon.Horses will be seen parading through the town tomorrowmorning as the traditional Rideout takes place,starting at am at Pinkie Pillars.While Pinkie St Peterrsquos Playing Field hosts Saturdayrsquos Festival Fun Day, with fairground rides, stalls, face painting, music and childrenrsquos entertainment filling the day with enjoyment for everyone.Festival Day will be capped with the even grander Festival Ball. Tickets are for sale at pound and can be purchased by contacting musselburghfestivalball@gmailSunday sees the fun continue as the Fisherrow Family Fun Day takes place at the harbour , featuring beach volleyball, beach rugby and beach tennis hand in hand with sandcastle competitions, crafts, a tug of war and a raft race.The Honest Lass and Honest Lad this year are Claire Dougal and Aidan Maguire, who have been busy throughout the week with their attendant Abbie Thomson.There have also been appearances from last yearrsquos Honest Lad and Honest Lass, Conor Scott and Katie McLaren.For more information about this yearrsquos festival, visit musselburghfestival.org
